The questioner raised an objection: Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadiš testified before Rabbi Eliezer: They used to buy wine with tithe money from the household of Abba. He said to him: Perhaps you only heard this when the fish guts were mixed in it. And even Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadiš did not say this except regarding wine, for it is the fat of the grape, but water and salt - no.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף:
human_translation: Rav Yosef said:
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said:

hebrew_text: לֹא נִצְרְכָה אֶלָּא שֶׁנָּתַן לְתוֹכָן שֶׁמֶן.
human_translation: was only necessary where one added oil to them.
llm_translation: Not needed except that was given to them oil.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִשּׁוּם שֶׁמֶן! לֹא צְרִיכָא, שֶׁנָּתַן דְּמֵי מַיִם וּמֶלַח בְּהַבְלָעָה.
human_translation: Abaye said to let him derive because of the oil No, it was necessary one paid the value of the water and salt by including
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: And let it come out because of oil! Not necessary, for he gave the value of water and salt in a case of swallowing.

hebrew_text: וּבְהַבְלָעָה מִי שְׁרֵי? אִין — וְהָתַנְיָא, בֶּן בַּג בַּג אוֹמֵר: ״בַּבָּקָר״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁלּוֹקְחִין בָּקָר עַל גַּב עוֹרוֹ. ״וּבַצֹּאן״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁלּוֹקְחִין צֹאן עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ. ״וּבַיַּיִן״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁלּוֹקְחִין יַיִן עַל גַּב קַנְקַנּוֹ. ״וּבַשֵּׁכָר״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁלּוֹקְחִין תֶּמֶד מִשֶּׁהֶחְמִיץ.
human_translation: But is one permitted by including Yes, and so it was taught Ben Bag Bag says “On oxen” teaches that one may buy an ox its hide. “On sheep” teaches that one may buy a sheep its fleece, “On wine” teaches that one may buy wine its jug. “On strong drink” teaches that one may buy mead, once it has fermented
llm_translation: In swallowing, who is exempt? None. And it was taught: Ben Bag Bag says: "In the morning" - this teaches that one may take a cow on its hide. "And in the sheep" - this teaches that one may take a sheep on its fleece. "And in the wine" - this teaches that one may take wine in its jug. "And in the vinegar" - this teaches that one may take vinegar from when it has soured.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאן דִּמְתַרְגֵּם לִי ״בַּבָּקָר״ אַלִּיבָּא דְּבֶן בַּג בַּג, מוֹבֵילְנָא מָאנֵיהּ אַבָּתְרֵיהּ לְבֵי מַסּוּתָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Whoever interprets “on oxen” for me in accordance with ben Bag Bag, I will carry his clothes after him into the bathhouse,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Whoever translates to me "in the morning" as the son of Bag Bag, we bring his father to the place of execution.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? כּוּלְּהוּ צְרִיכִי לְבַר מִ״בַּבָּקָר״, דְּלָא צְרִיךְ. מַאי צְרִיכִי? דְּאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״בַּבָּקָר״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: בָּקָר הוּא דְּמִזְדַּבַּן עַל גַּב עוֹרוֹ, מִשּׁוּם דְּגוּפֵיהּ הוּא. אֲבָל צֹאן עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ, דְּלָאו גּוּפֵיהּ הוּא — אֵימָא לָא.
human_translation: What is the reason All are necessary, except for “on oxen,” which is not necessary. what necessary? As, if the Torah had written “on oxen,” I might have said it is ox that may be bought with its hide because is its body, But sheep with its fleece, which is not its body say no,
llm_translation: "What is the reason? All of them are needed for 'בַּבָּקָר,' for it is not necessary. What is necessary? For if the Merciful One had written 'בַּבָּקָר,' I would have said: It is an ox that is slaughtered on account of its hide, because it is its body. But a sheep, on account of its fleece, for it is not its body — I would say no."

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״בַּצֹּאן״ עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: מִשּׁוּם דִּמְחוּבָּר בָּהּ. אֲבָל יַיִן עַל גַּב קַנְקַנּוֹ — אֵימָא לָא.
human_translation: And if the Torah had written “on sheep,” with its fleece, I might have said because is attached to it, But wine with its jug, say no,
llm_translation: And if the Merciful One wrote "in the flock" on its fleece, I would say: because it is connected to it. But wine on its jar - I would say no.

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״בַּיַּיִן״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: מִשּׁוּם דְּהַיְינוּ נְטִירוּתֵיהּ. אֲבָל תֶּמֶד מִשֶּׁהֶחְמִיץ דְּקִיּוּהָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא, אֵימָא לָא. כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״שֵׁכָר״.
human_translation: And if the Torah had written “on wine,” I might have said because is preservation, But mead that has fermented, which is mere acidity, say no, the Torah wrote: strong drink.”
llm_translation: If the Merciful One wrote "wine," I would say: because it is his preservation. But if it is vinegar, which is inherently sour, I would say no. The Merciful One wrote "strong drink."

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״בַּשֵּׁכָר״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: מַאי שֵׁכָר? דְּבֵילָה קְעִילִית, דְּפֵירָא הוּא. אֲבָל יַיִן עַל גַּב קַנְקַנּוֹ — אֵימָא לָא.
human_translation: And if the Torah had written “on strong drink,” I might have said: What is strong drink? Dried figs from Ke’ila, which are produce But wine with its jug, say no,
llm_translation: "And if the Merciful One had written 'in the shēkhār,' I would have said: What is shēkhār? A foolish thing, for it is beer. But wine upon its dregs — I would say no."

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא יַיִן עַל גַּב קַנְקַנּוֹ — דְּהַיְינוּ נְטִירוּתֵיהּ. אֲבָל צֹאן עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ — אֵימָא לָא. כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״צֹאן״, דַּאֲפִילּוּ עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ.
human_translation: And if the Torah had written wine with its jug is preservation. But sheep with its fleece, say no, the Torah stated sheep,” that even with its fleece.
llm_translation: If the Merciful One wrote "wine" on top of its stalk - that is, its pruning. But if "sheep" on top of its fleece - I would say no. The Merciful One wrote "sheep," indicating that even on top of its fleece.

hebrew_text: ״בַּבָּקָר״ לְמָה לִי?! וְכִי תֵּימָא: אִי לָא כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״בַּבָּקָר״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: צֹאן עַל גַּב עוֹרָהּ אִין, עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ לָא. כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״בַּבָּקָר״ לְאֵתוֹיֵי עוֹרוֹ. אִיַּיתַּר לֵיהּ ״צֹאן״ לְאֵתוֹיֵי גִּיזָּתָהּ.
human_translation: why do I “on oxen”? And if you say if the Torah had not written “on oxen,” I might have said a sheep with its hide, yes, with its fleece, no, the Torah wrote “on oxen,” to include its hide, sheep” remains to include its fleece,
llm_translation: "In the morning" - why do I need it?! And if you say: If the Merciful One did not write "in the morning," I would have said: On the back of its skin there is none, on the back of its fleece there is. The Merciful One wrote "in the morning" to include its skin. He needed to write "flock" to include its fleece.

hebrew_text: אִי לָא כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״בָּקָר״, לָא הֲוָה אָמֵינָא צֹאן עַל גַּב עוֹרָהּ — אִין, עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ — לָא. דְּאִם כֵּן, לִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״בָּקָר״, דְּמִמֵּילָא אִיַּיתַּר לֵיהּ ״צֹאן״.
human_translation: if the Torah had not written “on oxen,” I would not have said sheep with its hide, yes, with its fleece, no, if so, the Torah should have written oxen,” in which case sheep” would remain
llm_translation: If the Merciful One had written "cattle," I would not have said it refers to its wool — no, it refers to its hide. For if so, the Merciful One should have written "cattle," for the term "sheep" is already included in it.

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״צֹאן״, דַּאֲפִילּוּ עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ. ״בַּבָּקָר״ לְמָה לִי? הַשְׁתָּא צֹאן עַל גַּב גִּיזָּתָהּ מִיזְדַּבְּנָא, בָּקָר עַל גַּב עוֹרוֹ מִיבַּעְיָא? הַיְינוּ דְּקָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאן דִּמְתַרְגֵּם לִי ״בַּבָּקָר״ אַלִּיבָּא דְּבֶן בַּג בַּג, מוֹבֵילְנָא מָאנֵיהּ לְבֵי מַסּוּתָא.
human_translation: And since the Torah writes sheep,” even with its fleece, why do I need “on oxen”? now sheep may be bought with its fleece, is it necessary ox with its hide? This is what Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Whoever interprets “on oxen” for me in accordance with ben Bag Bag, I will carry his clothes after him into the bathhouse.
llm_translation: And since the Merciful One wrote "sheep," even on top of its fleece. "Cattle," why do I need? Now, sheep with its fleece is suitable for conversation, but cattle with its hide is required? That is what Rabbi Yochanan said: Whoever translates "cattle" to me according to the son of Bag Bag, we will bring him to the house of the council.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי קָא מִיפַּלְגִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן גָּדִישׁ וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר וְהָנֵי תַּנָּאֵי דִּלְקַמַּן? רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן גָּדִישׁ וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דָּרְשִׁי רִבּוּיֵי וּמִיעוּטֵי, וְהָנֵי תַּנָּאֵי דָּרְשִׁי כְּלָלֵי וּפְרָטֵי.
human_translation: With regard to what do Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish, and Rabbi Eliezer, and these tanna’im below, disagree? Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish and Rabbi Eliezer expound amplifications and restrictions, and these tanna’im expound generalizations and details,
llm_translation: With what do Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadiš and Rabbi Eliezer disagree, and those Tannaim who are mentioned later? Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadiš and Rabbi Eliezer interpreted inclusively and exclusively, and those Tannaim interpreted generalizations and specifications.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן גָּדִישׁ וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דָּרְשִׁי רִיבּוּיֵי וּמִיעוּטֵי. ״וְנָתַתָּה הַכֶּסֶף בְּכֹל אֲשֶׁר תְּאַוֶּה נַפְשְׁךָ״ — רִיבָּה, ״בַּבָּקָר וּבַצֹּאן וּבַיַּיִן וּבַשֵּׁכָר״ — מִיעֵט, ״וּבְכֹל אֲשֶׁר תִּשְׁאׇלְךָ נַפְשֶׁךָ״ — חָזַר וְרִיבָּה. רִיבָּה וּמִיעֵט וְרִיבָּה — רִיבָּה הַכֹּל. מַאי רַבִּי? רַבִּי כׇּל מִילֵּי. וּמַאי מִיעֵט? לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מִיעֵט צִיר, לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן גָּדִישׁ מִיעֵט מַיִם וּמֶלַח.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish and Rabbi Eliezer expound amplifications and restrictions. “And you shall bestow the money on all that your heart desires” it has amplified. “On oxen, on sheep, on wine, and on strong drink,” it has restricted “On whatever your soul requests,” it has again amplified. it amplified and restricted and amplified, it has amplified everything. What has it amplified It has amplified everything. And what has it restricted According to Rabbi Eliezer, it restricted brine according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Gadish, it restricted water and salt.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehudah ben Gadish and Rabbi Eliezer expounded: "And you shall give the money for whatever your soul desires" - this expands, "on cattle, on sheep, on wine, and on strong drink" - this limits, "and on whatever your soul may ask of you" - it reverts and expands. Expanding and limiting and expanding - expanding encompasses everything. What is Rabbi's opinion? Rabbi encompasses all matters. And what is limiting? According to Rabbi Eliezer, limiting is like a narrow bridge, while according to Rabbi Yehudah ben Gadish, limiting is water and salt.

hebrew_text: וְהָנֵי תַּנָּאֵי דָּרְשִׁי כְּלָלֵי וּפְרָטֵי. דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְנָתַתָּה הַכֶּסֶף בְּכֹל אֲשֶׁר תְּאַוֶּה נַפְשְׁךָ״ — כָּלַל, ״בַּבָּקָר וּבַצֹּאן וּבַיַּיִן וּבַשֵּׁכָר״ — פָּרַט, ״וּבְכֹל אֲשֶׁר תִּשְׁאׇלְךָ נַפְשֶׁךָ״ — חָזַר וְכָלַל. כְּלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל אִי אַתָּה דָן אֶלָּא כְּעֵין הַפְּרָט. וּמָה הַפְּרָט מְפוֹרָשׁ: פְּרִי מִפְּרִי, וְגִידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע, אַף כֹּל פְּרִי מִפְּרִי וְגִידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע.
human_translation: And these tanna’im expound generalizations and details, as it was taught “And you shall bestow the money on all that your heart desires” a generalization, “On cattle, on sheep, on wine, and on strong drink” a detail, “On whatever your soul requests,” it has generalized again, a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, you may deduce only similar to the detail. Just as the detail defined as the produce of produce, and grown from the ground, so all the produce of produce and are grown from the ground.
llm_translation: The following Tannaim expounded generalizations and specifications. As it was taught: "And you shall give the money for whatever your soul desires" — this is a generalization. "For cattle, for sheep, for wine, and for strong drink" — this is a specification. "And for whatever your soul asks of you" — it repeated and generalized. Generalization, specification, and generalization: you do not judge except in the manner of the specification. And what is the specification explicitly? Fruit from fruit, and the growths of the soil, so too, all fruit from fruit and the growths of the soil.

hebrew_text: וְתַנְיָא אִידַּךְ: מָה הַפְּרָט מְפוֹרָשׁ: וְלַד וַלְדוֹת הָאָרֶץ, אַף כֹּל וְלַד וַלְדוֹת הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: And it was taught in another Just as the detail defined as the offspring of the offspring of the earth, so all the offspring of the offspring of the earth.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught in another Baraita: What is the explicit detail? "And the offspring and the offspring of the land," just as all the offspring and the offspring of the land. English translation: And it was taught in another Baraita: What is the explicit detail? "And the offspring and the offspring of the land," just as all the offspring and the offspring of the land.

hebrew_text: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: דָּגִים אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר פְּרִי מִפְּרִי וְגִידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע, הָנֵי דָּגִים — גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע נִינְהוּ. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר וְלַד וַלְדוֹת הָאָרֶץ, דָּגִים — מִמַּיָּא אִיבְּרוֹ.
human_translation: What is between Abaye said: There is between them fish. According to the one who said the produce of produce and grown from the ground, fish are grown from the ground. according to the one who said the offspring of the offspring of the earth, fish were created from water.
llm_translation: What is the difference between them? Abaye said: Fish is the difference between them. According to the one who says "fruit from fruit and growths of the ground," those fish are growths of the ground. According to the one who says "and offspring and offspring's offspring of the earth," those fish were created from water.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר אַבָּיֵי דָּגִים גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע נִינְהוּ? וְהָאָמַר אַבָּיֵי:
human_translation: Did Abaye say fish are grown from the ground? Didn’t Abaye say the following?
llm_translation: And who said Abaye that fish are products of the ground? But didn't Abaye say:

hebrew_text: אָכַל פּוּטִיתָא — לוֹקֶה אַרְבַּע. נְמָלָה — לוֹקֶה חָמֵשׁ. צִירְעָה — לוֹקֶה שֵׁשׁ. וְאִם אִיתָא — פּוּטִיתָא נָמֵי לִילְקֵי מִשּׁוּם ״הַשֶּׁרֶץ הַשֹּׁרֵץ עַל הָאָרֶץ״!
human_translation: one ate a putita , he is given four lashes, an ant, he is given five lashes a hornet, he is given six lashes, And if it is a putita should also be given lashes for every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth
llm_translation: He who eats a fly - receives four lashes. A locust - receives five lashes. A hornet - receives six lashes. And if there is a doubt - regarding a fly, one should also receive lashes due to "the swarming thing that swarms upon the earth"!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבִינָא: עוֹפוֹת אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר פְּרִי מִפְּרִי וְגִידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע, הָנֵי נָמֵי — גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע נִינְהוּ. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר וְלַד וַלְדוֹת הָאָרֶץ, הָנֵי עוֹפוֹת — מִן הָרְקָק נִבְרְאוּ.
human_translation: Rather, Ravina said: There is between fowl. According to the one who said the produce of produce and grown from the ground, these are also grown from the ground. according to the one who said the offspring of the offspring of the earth, these fowl were created from mud
llm_translation: Rather, Ravina said: There is a distinction between birds. According to the one who says "fruit from fruit and growths of the ground," those also are growths of the ground. According to the one who says "and the offspring of the earth," those birds were created from mud.

hebrew_text: מַאן דִּמְרַבֵּי עוֹפוֹת — מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ, וּמַאן דִּמְמַעֵיט עוֹפוֹת — מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ?
human_translation: What is the reason of the one who includes fowl, and what is the reason of the one who excludes fowl?
llm_translation: The one who increases birds - what is his reason, and the one who decreases birds - what is his reason?

hebrew_text: מַאן דִּמְרַבֵּי עוֹפוֹת, קָסָבַר: כְּלָלָא בָּתְרָא דַּוְקָא. פְּרָט וּכְלָל — נַעֲשֶׂה כְּלָל מוּסָף עַל הַפְּרָט, וְאִיתְרַבּוּ לְהוּ כׇּל מִילֵּי. וְאַהְנִי כְּלָלָא קַמָּא לְמַעוֹטֵי כֹּל דְּלָא דָּמֵי לֵיהּ מִשְּׁנֵי צְדָדִין.
human_translation: The one who includes fowl holds the latter generalization is primary. a detail a generalization, the generalization is considered an addition to the detail, and all items are included. the first generalization is effective in excluding anything that is not similar to in two respects,
llm_translation: The one who argues regarding birds, holds: generalization follows specifically. Specific and general — the general is made as an addition to the specific, and they encompass all matters. And the first generalization excludes everything that is not similar to it from both sides.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דִּמְמַעֵט עוֹפוֹת, קָסָבַר: כְּלָלָא קַמָּא דַּוְוקָא, כְּלָל וּפְרָט — וְאֵין בַּכְּלָל אֶלָּא מַה שֶּׁבַּפְּרָט: הָנֵי — אִין, מִידֵּי אַחֲרִינָא — לָא. וְאַהְנִי כְּלָלָא בָּתְרָא לְרַבּוֹיֵי כֹּל דְּדָמֵי לֵיהּ מִשְּׁלֹשָׁה צְדָדִין.
human_translation: And the one who excludes fowl holds the first generalization is primary. generalization a detail, the generalization only includes that which is in the detail. these yes, something else, no, the latter generalization is effective to include anything that is similar to it in three respects,
llm_translation: The one who diminishes birds, holds: General principle precedes specific, general and particular — and in the general only what is in the particular: these — no, from others — yes. And this general at the end includes everything similar to it from three sides.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר שִׁילַת מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב: מְעָרְבִין בְּפַעְפּוּעִין וּבַחֲלַגְלוֹגוֹת וּבְגוּדְגְּדָנִיּוֹת, אֲבָל לֹא בַּחֲזִיז וְלֹא בְּכַפְנִיּוֹת.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said in the name of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, in the name Rav: One may establish an eiruv cress, purslane, and sweet clover, but not with green grain or with unripe dates.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav Shmuel bar Shilat: We may combine different types of wicks and different types of oils, but not with haziz or kapniyot.

hebrew_text: וּבְגוּדְגְּדָנִיּוֹת מִי מְעָרְבִין? וְהָתַנְיָא: גּוּדְגְּדָנִיּוֹת — מְרוּבֵּי בָנִים יֹאכֵלוּ, חֲשׂוּכֵי בָנִים לֹא יֹאכֵלוּ. וְאִם הוּקְשׁוּ לְזֶרַע — אַף מְרוּבֵּי בָּנִים לֹא יֹאכֵלוּ!
human_translation: But may one establish an eiruv with sweet clover? Wasn’t it taught sweet clover those who have many children may eat those without children may not eat and if it was hardened into seed, even those who have many children may not eat
llm_translation: And with regards to gudgadniyot, who may mix? And it was taught: Gudgadniyot - many children may eat, but children who are silent may not eat. And if they were difficult for the seed - even many children may not eat!

hebrew_text: תַּרְגְּמָא: אַשֶּׁלֹא הוּקְשׁוּ לְזֶרַע, וּמְרוּבֵּי בָנִים.
human_translation: Interpret that was not hardened into seed, and those who have many children
llm_translation: "Targema: Ashelo hukshu lezera, umeruvei banim."

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לְעוֹלָם לַחֲשׂוּכֵי בָנִים, דְּהָא חֲזוּ לִמְרוּבֵּי בָנִים. מִי לָא תְּנַן: מְעָרְבִין לַנָּזִיר בְּיַיִן וּלְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּתְרוּמָה. אַלְמָא: אַף עַל גַּב דְּלָא חֲזֵי לְהַאי — חֲזֵי לְהַאי. הָכָא נָמֵי, אַף עַל גַּב דְּלָא חֲזֵי לְהַאי — חֲזֵי לְהַאי.
human_translation: And if you wish, say actually, for those without children because it is fit those who have many children. Didn’t we learn One may establish an eiruv for a nazirite with wine, and for an Israelite with teruma ? Apparently, even though are not fit for this fit for that Here too, even though is not fit for this it is fit for that
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: Always be silent regarding sons, for they will eventually be many. Who taught us: We may mix wine for a Nazirite and for an Israelite with terumah. This implies: Even though you do not see this one — see that one. Here too, even though you do not see this one — see that one.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כִּי קָאָמַר רַב, בְּהַנְדְּקוֹקֵי מָדָאֵי.
human_translation: And if you wish, say When Rav said Median clover,
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: When Rav said, in matters of conjecture.

hebrew_text: וּבַחֲזִיז לָא? וְהָאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: כְּשׁוּת וַחֲזִיז מְעָרְבִין בָּהֶן, וּמְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶן ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״!
human_translation: And not with green grain? Didn’t Rav Yehuda say that Rav said: dodder and green grain, one may establish an eiruv with them; and them one recites the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground?
llm_translation: In the case of haziz, no? And Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: When one combines shush and haziz, they are mixed together, and one recites the blessing "Who creates the fruit of the earth" over them!

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא — מִקַּמֵּי דַּאֲתָא רַב לְבָבֶל, הָא — לְבָתַר דַּאֲתָא רַב לְבָבֶל.
human_translation: not difficult. This before Rav came to Babylonia. That after Rav came to Babylonia
llm_translation: Not difficult: this - before Rav came to Babylon, that - after Rav came to Babylon.

hebrew_text: וּבָבֶל הָוְיָא רוּבָּא דְּעָלְמָא? וְהָתַנְיָא: הַפּוֹל וְהַשְּׂעוֹרָה וְהַתִּילְתָּן שֶׁזְּרָעָן לְיָרָק — בָּטְלָה דַּעְתּוֹ אֵצֶל כׇּל אָדָם. לְפִיכָךְ: זַרְעָן חַיָּיב, וְיַרְקָן פָּטוּר. הַשַּׁחֲלַיִים וְהַגַּרְגִּיר שֶׁזְּרָעָן לְיָרָק — מִתְעַשְּׂרִין יָרָק וְזֶרַע, זְרָעָן לְזֶרַע — מִתְעַשְּׂרִין זֶרַע וְיָרָק.
human_translation: Is Babylonia the majority of the world? Wasn’t it taught beans, barley, and fenugreek that planted as an herb, his opinion is rendered irrelevant by the opinions of all other people? Therefore, one is obligated their seeds, and their herbs are exempt. cress and arugula, one planted them as herbs, they are tithed as herbs and as seeds; one planted them for seeds, they are tithed as seeds and as herbs,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And Babylon was the majority of the world? And it was taught: The beet, the barley, and the turnip, whose seed is for vegetables — his mind is nullified in the eyes of all people. Therefore: his seed is obligated, and his vegetable is exempt. The leek and the leek, whose seed is for vegetables — the vegetable and the seed are tithed, seed for seed — the seed and the vegetable are tithed." English translation:

hebrew_text: כִּי קָאָמַר רַב,
human_translation: When Rav said
llm_translation: When Rav said,

hebrew_text: בִּדְגִנּוּנְיָיתָא.
human_translation: to the garden variety,
llm_translation: In the grain market.

hebrew_text: זֶרַע גַּרְגִּיר. לְמַאי חֲזֵי? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שֶׁכֵּן רִאשׁוֹנִים שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה לָהֶן פִּלְפְּלִין, שׁוֹחֲקִין אוֹתוֹ וּמַטְבִּילִין בּוֹ אֶת הַצָּלִי.
human_translation: arugula seeds, For what are they suitable? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The earlier who had no pepper, would crush and dip roasted meat in them.
llm_translation: Seed of a gourd. For what purpose? Rabbi Yochanan said: Because the earlier ones did not have pepper, they would roast it and dip the roasted gourd in it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי זֵירָא כִּי הֲוָה חֲלִישׁ מִגִּרְסֵיהּ, הֲוָה אָזֵיל וְיָתֵיב אַפִּיתְחָא דְּרַב יְהוּדָה בַּר אַמֵּי, אָמַר: כִּי נָפְקִי וְעָיְילִי רַבָּנַן — אֵיקוּם מִקַּמַּיְיהוּ וַאֲקַבֵּל בְּהוּ אַגְרָא.
human_translation: when Rabbi Zeira was exhausted from his studies, he would go and sit at the entrance of Rav Yehuda bar Ami, say: When the Sages go in and out, I shall stand up before them and receive reward for them,
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira, when he was weak from his studies, would go and sit at the entrance of the house of Rav Yehuda bar Ami. He said: "When the Rabbis come out, I will rise before them and receive reward."

hebrew_text: נְפַק אֲתָא יָנוֹקָא דְּבֵי רַב, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי אַגְמְרָךְ רַבָּךְ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: כְּשׁוּת ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, חֲזִיז ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אַדְּרַבָּה, אִיפְּכָא מִיסְתַּבְּרָא, הַאי — מֵאַרְעָא קָא מִרַבֵּי, וְהַאי — מֵאַוֵּירָא קָא מִרַבֵּי.
human_translation: school child was leaving said to him: What did your teacher teach you He said to him: dodder Who creates the fruit of the ground; green grain By Whose word all things came to be. said to him: On the contrary, the opposite is reasonable, this, derives nourishment from the ground, whereas that, derives nourishment from the air,
llm_translation: He went out, Yanuka of the house of Rav, said to him: What did your teacher teach you? He said to him: Like the verse "Who creates the fruit of the earth," see "that everything comes into being by His word." He said to him: Adrabah, it is the opposite, this one — from the earth it increases, and this one — from the air it increases.

hebrew_text: וְהִלְכְתָא כְּיָנוֹקָא דְּבֵי רַב. מַאי טַעְמָא: הַאי — גְּמַר פֵּירֵי, וְהַאי — לָאו גְּמַר פֵּירֵי. וּמַאי דְּקָאָמְרַתְּ: הַאי מֵאַרְעָא קָא רָבֵי, וְהַאי מֵאַוֵּירָא קָא רָבֵי — לָא הִיא. כְּשׁוּת נָמֵי מֵאַרְעָא קָא רָבֵי, דְּהָא קָא חָזֵינַן דְּקָטְלִינַן לַהּ לְהִיזְמְתָא וּמָיְיתָא כְּשׁוּתָא.
human_translation: The halakha is in accordance with the school child. What is the reason This, fully ripened produce, and that, not fully ripened produce. And that which you said: This, derives nourishment from the ground, whereas that, derives nourishment from the air, this is not so. Dodder also derives nourishment from the ground, for we see that when the shrub is cut off, the dodder dies.
llm_translation: The halakha is like the opinion of the school of Rav. What is the reason? This one - he finishes the fruit, and this one - he does not finish the fruit. And what you are saying: This one is from the land of Rav, and this one is from the land of Avuira - it is not so. Rather, it is more fitting to say that this one is from the land of Rav, for we see that we kill for it to be pruned and to bring forth fruit.

hebrew_text: וּבְכַפְנִיּוֹת אֵין מְעָרְבִין? וְהָתַנְיָא: קוֹר נִיקָּח בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר, וְאֵין מִטַּמֵּא טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִין. וְכַפְנִיּוֹת נִקָּחוֹת בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר, וּמִטַּמְּאוֹת טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִים.
human_translation: And one may not establish an eiruv with unripe dates? Wasn’t it taught Heart of palm, may be bought with tithe money; but it does not contract the impurity of foods, And unripe dates may be bought with tithe money, and contract the impurity of foods.
llm_translation: In the corners, one does not mix produce for tithing? And it was taught: A beam can be acquired with silver of tithe, and it does not impart impurity of food. And corners can be acquired with silver of tithe, and they impart impurity of food.

hebrew_text: רָבֵי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: קוֹר הֲרֵי הוּא כְּעֵץ לְכׇל דְּבָרָיו — אֶלָּא שֶׁנִּיקָּח בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר, וְכַפְנִיּוֹת הֲרֵי הֵן כִּפְרִי לְכׇל דִּבְרֵיהֶם — אֶלָּא שֶׁפְּטוּרוֹת מִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says Heart of palm is like a tree in all its aspects, except that it may be bought with tithe money, And unripe dates are like fruit in all regards, except that they are exempt from tithes
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: A beam is like a tree in all its matters—except that it is acquired with silver of tithe, and its branches are like fruit in all their matters—except that they are exempt from tithe.

hebrew_text: הָתָם, בִּדְנִיסְחָנֵי.
human_translation: There, fruit never ripen
llm_translation: There, in D'Nischanay.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, בְּהָא לֵימָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה פְּטוּרוֹת מִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר? וְהָתַנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: לֹא הוּזְכְּרוּ פַּגֵּי בֵיתְיוֹנֵי אֶלָּא לְעִנְיַן מַעֲשֵׂר בִּלְבַד. פַּגֵּי בֵיתְיוֹנֵי וַאֲהִינֵי דְטוֹבִינָא חַיָּיבִין בְּמַעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: If so, would Rabbi Yehuda say with regard to this they are exempt from tithes? Wasn’t it taught Rabbi Yehuda said: The unripe figs of Beityoni were only mentioned with regard to tithes, the unripe figs of Beityoni, and the unripe dates of Tuvina, one is obligated to tithe them
llm_translation: So, in this case, with regard to this, Rabbi Yehuda said: Are they exempt from tithing? And it was taught: Rabbi Yehuda said: The poor of Beit Yonai were only mentioned in relation to tithing alone. The poor of Beit Yonai and the residents of Tovina are obligated in tithing.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְעוֹלָם לָאו בְּנִיסְחָנֵי, וּלְעִנְיַן טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִין שָׁאנֵי, כִּדְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הוֹאִיל וְרָאוּי לְמַתְּקָן עַל יְדֵי הָאוּר, הָכָא נָמֵי: הוֹאִיל וְיָכוֹל לְמַתְּקָן עַל יְדֵי הָאוּר.
human_translation: Rather, Actually, is not referring to fruit never ripen, pertaining to the impurity of foods is different, As Rabbi Yoḥanan said Since they are fit to be sweetened through fire, here too, Since they are fit to be sweetened through fire,
llm_translation: Rather, forever not in Nischanai, and for the matter of the impurity of foods they differ, as Rabbi Yochanan said: Since it is fit to be fixed by means of fire, here it is stated: Since it is possible to be fixed by means of fire.

hebrew_text: וְהֵיכָא אִתְּמַר דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן? אַהָא דְּתַנְיָא: שְׁקֵדִים הַמָּרִים — קְטַנִּים חַיָּיבִין, גְּדוֹלִים פְּטוּרִין. מְתוּקִים — גְּדוֹלִים חַיָּיבִין, קְטַנִּים פְּטוּרִין. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם אָבִיו: זֶה וָזֶה, לִפְטוּר. וְאָמְרִי לַהּ: זֶה וָזֶה לְחִיּוּב. אָמַר רַבִּי אִילְעָא: הוֹרָה רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בְּצִיפּוֹרִי כְּדִבְרֵי הָאוֹמֵר זֶה וְזֶה לִפְטוּר.
human_translation: Where was Rabbi Yoḥanan stated? on this which was taught obligated bitter almonds small large, exempt obligated to sweet, large exempt from small ones, Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yosei, said in the name of his father: exempt from both this and that, And some say obligated to both this and that. Rabbi Ila said: Rabbi Ḥanina ruled in Tzippori in accordance with the one who said: exempt from both this and that.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And where was it stated that Rabbi Yochanan said? Here, as it was taught: Bitter almonds - small ones are obligated, large ones are exempt. Sweet almonds - large ones are obligated, small ones are exempt. Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in the name of his father: Both this and that are exempt. And some say: Both this and that are obligated. Rabbi Ilai said: Rabbi Chanina taught in Tzipori according to the words of the one who says both this and that are exempt.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר זֶה וָזֶה לְחִיּוּב, לְמַאי חֲזֵי? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הוֹאִיל וְרָאוּי לְמַתְּקָן עַל יְדֵי הָאוּר.
human_translation: According to the one who said obligated to both this and that, for what are suitable? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Since are fit to be sweetened through fire,
llm_translation: And for the one who says both this and that are obligatory, for what does he see? Rabbi Yochanan said: Since it is fitting to be rectified by means of light.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: קוֹר הֲרֵי הוּא כְּעֵץ לְכׇל דְּבָרָיו, אֶלָּא שֶׁנִּיקָּח בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר. הַיְינוּ תַּנָּא קַמָּא!
human_translation: The Master said Rabbi Yehuda says: Heart of palm is like a tree in all its aspects, except that it may be bought with tithe money. is the first tanna .
llm_translation: Master said, Rabbi Yehuda says: A beam is like a tree in all its matters, except that it is acquired with silver tithe. This is the first teaching!

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שְׁלָקוֹ וְטִגְּנוֹ אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ.
human_translation: Abaye said: There is between them one boiled or fried
llm_translation: Abbaye said: "They quarreled and argued."

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רָבָא: מִי אִיכָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר שְׁלָקוֹ וְטִגְּנוֹ לָא? וְהָתַנְיָא: הָעוֹר וְהַשִּׁילְיָא אֵין מִטַּמְּאִין טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִין. עוֹר שֶׁשְּׁלָקוֹ, וְשִׁילְיָא שֶׁחִישֵּׁב עָלֶיהָ — מִטַּמְּאִין טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִין!
human_translation: Rava strongly objects to this: Is there anyone who said one boiled or fried it, not Wasn’t it taught The hide and the placenta do not contract the impurity of foods; a hide that one boiled and a placenta that one intended do contract the impurity of foods?
llm_translation: Rava objects to this: Who is there according to the one who says that if it was rinsed and cooked, it is not considered susceptible to impurity? But it was taught: Skin and fat do not contract impurity of foods. Skin that was rinsed, and fat that was placed upon it - they contract impurity of foods!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ בְּרָכָה. דְּאִתְּמַר: קוֹר — רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: There is between them the blessing for it was stated Rav Yehuda said Who creates the fruit of the ground. And Shmuel said By Whose word all things came to be.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: There is a difference between them in the blessing. As it was stated: "Kore" - Rav Yehudah said: "Who creates the fruit of the earth," and Shmuel said: "That everything comes into being through His word."

hebrew_text: רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר: ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״ — אוּכְלָא הוּא. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: ״שֶׁהַכֹּל נִהְיֶה בִּדְבָרוֹ״ — כֵּיוָן שֶׁסּוֹפוֹ לְהַקְשׁוֹת, לָא מְבָרְכִינַן עִילָּוֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Who creates the fruit of the ground, as it is food. And Shmuel said By Whose word all things came to be. Since it will eventually harden we do not recite over it the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground,
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said: "Bo'rei p'ri ha'adamah" - it is a blessing. And Shmuel said: "Shehakol niheyeh bidvaro" - since its end is to harden, we do not recite over it "Bo'rei p'ri ha'adamah."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ שְׁמוּאֵל לְרַב יְהוּדָה: שִׁינָּנָא, כְּווֹתָיךְ מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּהָא צְנוֹן שֶׁסּוֹפוֹ לְהַקְשׁוֹת, וּמְבָרְכִינַן עֲלֵיהּ ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״.
human_translation: Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: Shinnana , your opinion is reasonable, as a radish will eventually harden, and we recite over it the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground.
llm_translation: Shmuel said to Rav Yehudah: Shinana, your beard is well arranged, for a radish, whose end is liable to rot, and we recite over it "Who creates the fruit of the earth."

hebrew_text: וְלָא הִיא, צְנוֹן נָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְפוּגְלָא, דִּיקְלָא — לָא נָטְעִי אִינָשֵׁי אַדַּעְתָּא דְקוֹרָא. וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּקַלְּסֵיהּ שְׁמוּאֵל לְרַב יְהוּדָה, הִלְכְתָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל.
human_translation: But it is not so, people plant radish with the intention soft; but people do not plant palm trees with the intention heart of palm. And Even though Shmuel praised Rav Yehuda, the halakha is in accordance with Shmuel.
llm_translation: And not this, a fig tree planted by people of knowledge of the palm tree - not planted by people of knowledge of the vine. And even though Shmuel criticized it to Rav Yehuda, the halakha follows the opinion of Shmuel.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא, אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: כְּשׁוּת וַחֲזִיז מְעָרְבִין בָּהֶן, וּמְבָרְכִין עֲלֵיהֶם ״בּוֹרֵא פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה״. כְּשׁוּת בְּכַמָּה? כִּדְאָמַר רַב יְחִיאֵל: כִּמְלֹא הַיָּד — הָכָא נָמֵי כִּמְלֹא הַיָּד.
human_translation: the matter itself Rav Yehuda said that Rav said dodder and green grain: One may establish an eiruv with them, and them one recites the blessing: Who creates the fruit of the ground. How much dodder As Rav Yeḥiel said A handful. Here, too, a handful.
llm_translation: The body, Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: When beets and lettuce are mixed together, one recites the blessing "Blessed is the Creator of the fruit of the ground" over them. How much is considered a mixture? As Rav Yechiel said: The size of a handbreadth - here too, the size of a handbreadth.

hebrew_text: חֲזִיז בְּכַמָּה? אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר טוֹבִיָּה בַּר יִצְחָק אָמַר רַב: כִּמְלֹא אוּזִילְתָּא דְאִיכָּרֵי.
human_translation: how much green grain Rabba bar Toviya bar Yitzḥak said that Rav said: A full farmers’ bundle.
llm_translation: Vision in how many? Rabba bar Toviya bar Yitzchak said Rav: Like the size of the hole of a needle.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר רַב חִלְקִיָּה בַּר טוֹבִיָּה: מְעָרְבִין בְּקִלְיָא. בְּקִלְיָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ?! אֶלָּא בְּיַרְקָא דְקִלְיָא, וְכַמָּה? אָמַר רַב יְחִיאֵל: כִּמְלֹא הַיָּד.
human_translation: Rav Ḥilkiya bar Toviya said: One may establish an eiruv with glasswort. Does it enter your mind with glasswort? Rather, with the herb from glasswort And how much Rav Yeḥiel said: A handful.
llm_translation: Rav Chilkiyah bar Toviya said: We mix in a basket. In a basket, is that your opinion?! Rather, in the green of the basket, and how much? Rav Yechiel said: Like the size of a hand.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה נְפַק לְקִירְיָיתָא, בְּעוֹ מִינֵּיהּ: מַהוּ לְעָרֵב בְּפוֹלִין לַחִין? לָא הֲוָה בִּידֵיהּ. כִּי אֲתָא לְבֵי מִדְרְשָׁא, אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ: הָכִי אָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי: מְעָרְבִין בְּפוֹלִין לַחִין. וְכַמָּה? אָמַר רַב יְחִיאֵל: כִּמְלֹא הַיָּד.
human_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya went out to villages, asked him: What is to establishing an eiruv with moist beans? He did not have When he came to the study hall, they said to him: This is what Rabbi Yannai said: One may establish an eiruv with moist beans. And how much Rav Yeḥiel said: A handful.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yirmeya went out to the town of Kiryatya, they asked him: What about mixing in Poland with vinegar? It was not in his hands. When he came to the study hall, they said to him: Did not Rabbi Yannai say: We mix in Poland with vinegar. And how much? Rabbi Yechiel said: The size of a hand.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הַמְנוּנָא: מְעָרְבִין בִּתְרָדִין חַיִּין. אִינִי? וְהָאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: סִילְקָא חַיָּיא קָטֵיל גַּבְרָא חַיָּיא!
human_translation: Rav Hamnuna said: One may establish an eiruv with raw beets. Is that so? Didn’t Rav Ḥisda say: Raw beet kills a healthy person,
llm_translation: Rav Hamnuna said: We mix wine with water. Is it not so? But didn't Rav Ḥisdah say: A drop of wine kills a man!

hebrew_text: הָהוּא, בִּבְשִׁיל וְלָא בְּשִׁיל.
human_translation: That to that was partially cooked,
llm_translation: That one, in boiling and not boiling.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַב הַמְנוּנָא: אֵין מְעָרְבִין בִּתְרָדִין חַיִּין, דְּאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: סִילְקָא חַיָּיא קָטֵיל גַּבְרָא חַיָּיא. וְהָא קָא חָזֵינַן דְּקָא אָכְלִי וְלָא מָיְיתִי? הָתָם בִּבְשִׁיל וְלָא בְּשִׁיל.
human_translation: There are who say Rav Hamnuna said: One may not establish an eiruv with raw beets, Rav Ḥisda said: Raw beet kills a healthy person. Don’t we see eating it and they do not die? There, to that was partially cooked,
llm_translation: There are some who say, Rav Hamnuna said: One does not mix wine in Tardina, as Rav Chisda said: A drop of wine kills a drop of man. But we see that they ate and were not harmed? There, it was cooked and not raw.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: תַּבְשִׁיל שֶׁל תְּרָדִין יָפֶה לַלֵּב וְטוֹב לָעֵינַיִם, וְכׇל שֶׁכֵּן לִבְנֵי מֵעַיִים. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: וְהוּא דְּיָתֵיב אַבֵּי תָפֵי וְעָבֵיד תּוֹךְ תּוֹךְ.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: A cooked dish of beets is beneficial for the heart, good for the eyes, and all the more so for the intestines. Abaye said: That is sits on the stove and makes a tukh tukh
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: A dish of beets is good for the heart and beneficial for the eyes, and all the more so for the children of the stomach. Abbaye said: And this is when Abba Tafi is sitting and stirring within.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: הֲרֵינִי כְּבֶן עַזַּאי בְּשׁוּקֵי טְבֶרְיָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ הָהוּא מֵרַבָּנַן לְרָבָא: תַּפּוּחִים בְּכַמָּה? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְכִי מְעָרְבִין בְּתַפּוּחִים?
human_translation: Rava said Behold, I am like ben Azzai, in the markets of Tiberias. One of the Sages said to Rava: How many apples said to him: Does one establish an eiruv with apples?
llm_translation: Rava said: "Behold, I am like Ben Azai in the markets of Tiberias." That certain scholar said to Rava: "Apples at what price?" He said to him: "Do we mix apples?"

hebrew_text: וְלָא? וְהָתְנַן: כׇּל הָאוֹכָלִין מִצְטָרְפִין לִפְסוֹל אֶת הַגְּוִויָּה בַּחֲצִי פְרָס, וּבִמְזוֹן שְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת לְעֵירוּב, וּכְבֵיצָה לְטַמֵּא טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִים!
human_translation: And not Didn’t we learn All foods combine to disqualify the body half of a half-loaf and food two meals for an eiruv , and an egg-bulk to contract the impurity of foods?
llm_translation: And not? And we learned in a Mishnah: All foods combine to disqualify the ritual bath when they are worth half a Perutah, and with regard to the Eruv, two meals' worth of sustenance, and like an egg to impart impurity to food!

hebrew_text: וְהַאי מַאי תְּיוּבְתָּא? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָתָנֵי ״כׇּל הָאוֹכָלִין״, וְהָנֵי בְּנֵי אֲכִילָה נִינְהוּ — וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֵין לְמֵדִין מִן הַכְּלָלוֹת וַאֲפִילּוּ בִּמְקוֹם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר בּוֹ ״חוּץ״!
human_translation: And what is the refutation? If you say because it was taught all foods, and these are fit for eating, Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: One may not learn from general statements even in a place where it says except,
llm_translation: And what is the reason for this preference? If you say it is because it teaches "all foods," and these are considered foods for consumption - but didn't Rabbi Yochanan say: We do not learn from generalizations, even in a case where it says "except"!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָתָנֵי ״וּבִמְזוֹן שְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת לְעֵירוּב וּכְבֵיצָה לְטַמֵּא טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִין״. וְהָנֵי נָמֵי בְּנֵי טַמּוֹיֵי טוּמְאַת אוֹכָלִין נִינְהוּ.
human_translation: Rather, because it taught: And food two meals for an eiruv , and an egg-bulk to contract the impurity of foods; and these are also susceptible to the impurity of foods.
llm_translation: Rather, because it is taught: "And with food, two meals for an Eruv, and like an egg for rendering food susceptible to impurity." And these are the same as the sons of those who are susceptible to the impurity of food.

hebrew_text: וְכַמָּה? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: תַּפּוּחִים בְּקַב.
human_translation: How many Rav Naḥman said: apples a kav .
llm_translation: And how much? Rav Nachman said: Apples in a kab.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: עוּכְלָא תַּבְלִין, וְלִיטְרָא יָרָק, וַעֲשָׂרָה אֱגוֹזִין, וַחֲמִשָּׁה אֲפַרְסְקִין, וּשְׁנֵי רִמּוֹנִים, וְאֶתְרוֹג אֶחָד. וְאָמַר גּוּרְסַק בַּר דָּרֵי מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב מְנַשְּׁיָא בַּר שְׂגוּבְלִי מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב, וְכֵן לְעֵירוּב. וְהָנֵי נָמֵי לִיהְווֹ כִּי אֲפַרְסְקִין!
human_translation: raises an objection Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: an ukla , of spices, a liter of vegetables, ten nuts, five peaches, two pomegranates, one citron, And Gursak bar Darei said in the name of Rav Menashya bar Sheguvlei, in the name of Rav: And similarly, with regard to an eiruv . These should also be like peaches,
llm_translation: The question was raised: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: A dried fig, a lettuce, ten nuts, five persimmons, two pomegranates, and one citron. And Gursak son of Dara, from the name of Rav Menashya bar Segubli, from the name of Rav, said likewise for an Eruv. And these are considered as persimmons!

hebrew_text: הָנֵי חֲשִׁיבִי, וְהָנֵי לָא חֲשִׁיבִי.
human_translation: These are important, but these are not important,
llm_translation: These are considered significant, and these are not considered significant.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: שְׁרָא לֵיהּ מָרֵיהּ לְרַב מְנַשְּׁיָא בַּר שְׂגוּבְלִי, אֲנָא אַמְרִיתָא נִיהֲלֵיהּ אַמַּתְנִיתִין, וְהוּא אַמְרַהּ אַבָּרַיְיתָא. דִּתְנַן: אֵין פּוֹחֲתִין לְעָנִי בַּגּוֹרֶן מֵחֲצִי קַב חִטִּין וְקַב שְׂעוֹרִין. רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: חֲצִי קַב שְׂעוֹרִין. וְקַב וַחֲצִי כוּסְּמִין, וְקַב גְּרוֹגְרוֹת אוֹ מָנֶה דְּבֵילָה. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: פְּרָס. וַחֲצִי לוֹג יַיִן, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: רְבִיעִית. וּרְבִיעִית שֶׁמֶן, רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: שְׁמִינִית. וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַפֵּירוֹת, אָמַר אַבָּא שָׁאוּל: כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּמְכְּרֵם וְיִקַּח בָּהֶן מְזוֹן שְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת. וְאָמַר רַב: וְכֵן לְעֵירוּב.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: May his Master, forgive Rav Menashya bar Sheguvlei, I stated before him concerning a mishna, and he stated it concerning the baraita , As we learned One may not give a pauper at the threshing floor less than half a kav of wheat or a kav of barley. Rabbi Meir says: half a kav of barley. a kav and a half of spelt, a kav of dried figs, or a maneh of pressed figs. Rabbi Akiva says: half half a log of wine. Rabbi Akiva says: a quarter And a quarter of oil. Rabbi Akiva says: an eighth And all other fruit, Abba Shaul said: enough to sell them and buy food for two meals with their And Rav said: And similarly, with regard to an eiruv .
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: His master permitted Rav Menashya bar Segubli to him, I said a statement of a Mishnah, and he said a statement of the Aramaic. As we learned in a Mishnah: One may not give less than half a kav of wheat and a kav of barley to a poor person in the granary. Rabbi Meir says: Half a kav of barley. And a kav and a half of carobs, and a kav of dried figs or a mane of dates. Rabbi Akiva says: A Persian. And half a log of wine, Rabbi Akiva says: A quarter. And a quarter of oil, Rabbi Akiva says: An eighth. And for all other fruits, Abba Shaul said: Sufficient for him to sell them and buy with them food for two meals. And Rav said: The same applies for an Eruv.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי אוּלְמֵיהּ דְּהַאי מֵהָךְ? אִילֵּימָא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא תָּנֵי בְּהָךְ תַּבְלִין, וְתַבְלִין לָאו בְּנֵי אֲכִילָה נִינְהוּ — אַטּוּ הָכָא מִי לָא קָתָנֵי חִטִּין וּשְׂעוֹרִין, וְלָאו בְּנֵי אֲכִילָה נִינְהוּ!
human_translation: What is the strength of this over that? If you say because spices was taught in this and spices are not fit for eating wasn’t wheat and barley taught here and they are not fit for eating
llm_translation: And what is the reason for this mixture of this dish? If you say it is because he is teaching about spices in that dish, and spices are not considered food — then here, why doesn't he teach about wheat and barley, which are also not considered food!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָתָנֵי חֲצִי לוֹג יַיִן, וְאָמַר רַב: מְעָרְבִין בִּשְׁתֵּי רְבִיעִיּוֹת שֶׁל יַיִן. מִדְּבָעִינַן כּוּלֵּי הַאי — שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ כִּי אָמַר רַב ״וְכֵן לְעֵירוּב״ — אַהָא מַתְנִיתִין קָאָמַר. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Rather, it is because it was taught half a log of wine. And Rav said: One may establish an eiruv with two-quarters of wine, Since we require so much learn from here when Rav said: And similarly, with regard to an eiruv , he said it about this mishna conclude from this
llm_translation: Rather, because it teaches half a log of wine, and Rav said: We mix with two quarters of wine. Since we require all of this - hear from it that Rav said, "And similarly for an Eruv" - ah, the Mishnah is saying. Hear from it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: וּבִמְזוֹן שְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת לְעֵירוּב. סָבַר רַב יוֹסֵף לְמֵימַר: עַד דְּאִיכָּא סְעוּדָה מֵהַאי וּסְעוּדָה מֵהַאי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבָּה: אֲפִילּוּ לְמֶחֱצָה לִשְׁלִישׁ וְלִרְבִיעַ.
human_translation: The Master said: And food for two meals for an eiruv . Rav Yosef thought to say unless there is meal of this and meal of that Rabba said to him: even half, a third, or a quarter
llm_translation: Master said: And with food, two meals for an Eruv. Rav Yosef thought to say: Until there is a meal from this and a meal from that. Rabbah said to him: Even if it is half, a third, or a quarter.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא, אָמַר רַב: מְעָרְבִין בִּשְׁתֵּי רְבִיעִיּוֹת שֶׁל יַיִן. וּמִי בָּעִינַן כּוּלֵּי הַאי? וְהָתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: יַיִן כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל בּוֹ, חוֹמֶץ כְּדֵי לְטַבֵּל בּוֹ, זֵיתִים וּבְצָלִים כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל בָּהֶן שְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת?
human_translation: itself, Rav said: One may establish an eiruv with two-quarters of wine. Do we need so much? Wasn’t it taught Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: wine enough to eat with it, vinegar enough to dip in it, olives and onions enough to eat them two meals.
llm_translation: The body, Rav said: One may mix with two quarters of wine. And do we require all this? And it was taught, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Wine for eating with it, vinegar for dipping in it, olives and onions for eating two meals with them?

hebrew_text: הָתָם בְּחַמְרָא מְבַשְּׁלָא.
human_translation: There, to cooked wine,
llm_translation: There, in a pot, he cooks.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: חוֹמֶץ כְּדֵי לְטַבֵּל בּוֹ. אָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב: כְּדֵי לְטַבֵּל בּוֹ מְזוֹן שְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת שֶׁל יָרָק. אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַב גִּידֵּל אָמַר רַב: יָרָק הַנֶּאֱכָל בִּשְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת.
human_translation: The Master said vinegar is enough to dip in it. Rav Giddel said that Rav said: Enough to dip in it the food of two meals of vegetables. Some say Rav Giddel said that Rav said: vegetables that are eaten in two meals,
llm_translation: Master said: vinegar for dipping in it. Rav Giddel said Rav said: for dipping in it, the sustenance of two meals of vegetables. Some say, Rav Giddel said Rav said: vegetables that are eaten in two meals.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: זֵיתִים וּבְצָלִים כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל בָּהֶן מְזוֹן שְׁתֵּי סְעוּדוֹת. וּבִבְצָלִים מִי מְעָרְבִין? וְהָתַנְיָא: אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר: פַּעַם אַחַת שָׁבַת רַבִּי מֵאִיר בְּעַרְדִּיסְקָא, וּבָא אָדָם אֶחָד לְפָנָיו, אָמַר לוֹ: רַבִּי, עֵירַבְתִּי בִּבְצָלִים לְטִיבְעִין, וְהוֹשִׁיבוֹ רַבִּי מֵאִיר בְּאַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת שֶׁלּוֹ.
human_translation: The Master said olives and onions to eat them the food of two meals. May one establish an eiruv with onions? Wasn’t it taught Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Rabbi Meir once spent Shabbat in Ardiska, and a certain person came before him said to him: Rabbi, I made an eiruv with onions, Tiv’in. And Rabbi Meir made him remain within his four cubits.
llm_translation: Master said: olives and onions, for the purpose of eating with them a meal of two courses. And with onions, who may combine? And it was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Once, on Shabbat, Rabbi Meir was in Ardiska, and a man came before him, and said to him: Rabbi, I have combined onions for an eruv, and Rabbi Meir established for him a four cubit domain.

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּעָלִים, הָא בְּאִימָּהוֹת. דְּתַנְיָא: אָכַל בָּצָל וְהִשְׁכִּים וּמֵת, אֵין אוֹמְרִין מִמָּה מֵת. וְאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בֶּעָלִים, אֲבָל בְּאִימָּהוֹת — לֵית לַן בַּהּ. וּבְעָלִין נָמֵי לָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא
human_translation: not difficult. This to leaves, that to bulbs, As it was taught ate an onion and died early we need not ask from what he died, And Shmuel said: They only taught with regard to the leaves; but with regard to bulbs, we have no with it. And even with regard to the leaves, we only stated
llm_translation: Not difficult: here in owners, here in mothers. As it was taught: one who ate onion and slept and died, we do not say from what did he die. And Shmuel said: they only taught about owners, but about mothers - we do not have it. And owners also did not say except.

hebrew_text: דְּלָא אִבְּצִיל זִירְתָּא, אֲבָל אִבְּצִיל זִירְתָּא — לֵית לַן בַּהּ.
human_translation: has not grown a span, however, if it has grown a span, we have no with it.
llm_translation: If one did not separate the chaff, but separated the chaff - we do not have it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: לָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא דְּלָא אִישְׁתִּי שִׁיכְרָא, אֲבָל אִישְׁתִּי שִׁיכְרָא לֵית לַן בַּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: We only stated one did not drink beer however, if he drank beer we have no with it.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: We only said this regarding my wife's beer, but my wife's beer we do not have.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: לֹא יֹאכַל אָדָם בָּצָל, מִפְּנֵי נָחָשׁ שֶׁבּוֹ. וּמַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא שֶׁאָכַל חֲצִי בָצָל וַחֲצִי נָחָשׁ שֶׁבּוֹ וְחָלָה וְנָטָה לָמוּת, וּבִקְּשׁוּ חֲבֵירָיו רַחֲמִים עָלָיו וְחָיָה, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהַשָּׁעָה צְרִיכָה לוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught A person should not eat onion because of toxins in it. There was an incident with Rabbi Ḥanina, who ate half an onion and half of its toxins, and he fell deathly ill, and his colleagues prayed for mercy for him, and he survived. because the time needed him,
llm_translation: The Sages taught: A person should not eat an onion because of the snake within it. And it happened with Rabbi Chanina that he ate half an onion and half a snake within it, and he fell ill and was close to death. His colleagues prayed for mercy on his behalf, and he lived, because the hour required it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: שֵׁכָר מְעָרְבִין בּוֹ, וּפוֹסֵל אֶת הַמִּקְוֶה בִּשְׁלֹשֶׁת לוּגִּין. מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַב כָּהֲנָא: פְּשִׁיטָא, וְכִי מָה בֵּין זֶה לְמֵי צֶבַע? דִּתְנַן: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: מֵי צֶבַע פּוֹסְלִין אֶת הַמִּקְוֶה בִּשְׁלֹשֶׁת לוּגִּין. אָמְרִי: הָתָם מַיָּא דְצִבְעָא מִיקְּרֵי, הָכָא שִׁיכְרָא אִיקְּרִי.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said that Shmuel said: One may establish an eiruv with beer, and it invalidates a ritual bath with three log , Rav Kahana strongly objects to this: obvious, for what is the difference between this and dye-water? As we learned Rabbi Yosei says: Dye-water invalidates a ritual bath with three log , They said: there, is called dye-water; here, it is called beer.
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said in the name of Shmuel: Beer can be used to mix with it, and it invalidates the mikveh with three logs. Rav Kahana objected to him: It is obvious, what is the difference between this and colored water? As we learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Yosei says: Colored water invalidates the mikveh with three logs. They said: There, it is called water of dye, here it is called beer.

hebrew_text: וּבְכַמָּה מְעָרְבִין? סָבַר רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף לְמֵימַר: בִּתְרֵין רִבְעֵי שִׁכְרָא, כְּדִתְנַן: הַמּוֹצִיא יַיִן, כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת הַכּוֹס. וְתָנֵי עֲלַהּ: כְּדֵי מְזִיגַת כּוֹס יָפֶה. מַאי כּוֹס יָפֶה? כּוֹס שֶׁל בְּרָכָה. וְאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר אֲבוּהּ: כּוֹס שֶׁל בְּרָכָה צָרִיךְ שֶׁיְּהֵא בּוֹ רוֹבַע רְבִיעִית, כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּמְזְגֶנּוּ וְיַעֲמוֹד עַל רְבִיעִית. וְכִדְרָבָא, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: כֹּל חַמְרָא דְּלָא דָּרֵי עַל חַד תְּלָת מַיָּא — לָאו חַמְרָא הוּא.
human_translation: And how much establish an eiruv ? Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Yosef, thought to say before Rav Yosef Two-quarters of beer. As we learned one carries out wine enough for diluting a cup, And was taught about Enough for diluting a fine cup. What a fine cup? A cup of blessing. And Rav Naḥman said that Rabba bar Avuh said: A cup of blessing must contain a quarter of a quarter- so that dilutes it amounts to a quarter- And in accordance with Rava as Rava said: Any wine that is not diluted three water to one is not wine.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And with how much do we mix? Rav Acha, son of Rav Yosef thought before Rav Yosef to say: With two quarters of a log, as we learned: One who pours wine, enough for the cup to be filled. And it was taught about it: enough for a beautiful cup to be filled. What is a beautiful cup? A cup of blessing. And Rav Nachman said in the name of Rabba bar Avuh: A cup of blessing needs to have a quarter of a quarter, so that one can mix it and it will stand on a quarter. And like Rava, for Rava said: Any wine that does not hold on one to three parts of water - it is not wine."

hebrew_text: וְקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַמַּשְׁקִין בִּרְבִיעִית, וְכׇל הַשּׁוֹפְכִין בִּרְבִיעִית. מִדְּהָתָם עַל חַד אַרְבַּע — הָכָא נָמֵי עַל חַד אַרְבַּע.
human_translation: And we learned in the latter clause And all other liquids, and all waste water, a quarter- Since there, one to four, here, too, one to four
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it is taught in the latter clause: And all other liquids in a quarter-log measure, and all liquids that are poured in a quarter-log measure. Just as there, it is on one of four sides, so too here, it is on one of four sides.

hebrew_text: וְלָא הִיא, הָתָם הוּא דִּבְצִיר מֵהֲכִי לָא חֲשִׁיב, אֲבָל הָכָא — לָא. דַּעֲבִידִי אִינָשֵׁי דְּשָׁתוּ כָּסָא בְּצַפְרָא וְכָסָא בְּפַנְיָא, וְסָמְכִי עִילָּוַיְהוּ.
human_translation: And this is not so. There, less than that is insignificant. However, here, not as it is common for people to drink a cup in the morning and a cup in the evening, and they rely on them
llm_translation: And not it, there it is, that is why it is not considered, but here - no. For people make a chair in the morning and a chair in the evening, and they lean on them.

hebrew_text: תְּמָרִים בְּכַמָּה? אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: תְּמָרִים בְּקַב. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ? דְּתַנְיָא: אָכַל גְּרוֹגְרוֹת וְשִׁילֵּם תְּמָרִים — תָּבוֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה.
human_translation: How many dates Rav Yosef said: dates a kav . Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this As it was taught ate dried figs and paid dates may a blessing come upon him.
llm_translation: Dates at what quantity? Said Rav Yosef: Dates at a kab. Said Rav Yosef: From where do I say this? As it was taught: One who eats dried figs and then eats dates - a blessing comes upon him.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא לְפִי דָמִים, דַּאֲכַל מִינֵּיהּ בְּזוּזָא וְקָא מְשַׁלֵּם לֵיהּ בְּזוּזָא — מַאי ״תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה״? בְּזוּזָא אֲכַל, בְּזוּזָא קָא מְשַׁלֵּם! אֶלָּא לָאו, לְפִי מִדָּה, דַּאֲכַל מִינֵּיהּ גְּרִיוָא דִּגְרוֹגְרוֹת דְּשָׁוְיָא זוּזָא, וְקָא מְשַׁלֵּם לֵיהּ גְּרִיוָא דִתְמָרִים דְּשָׁוֵי אַרְבְּעָה — וְקָתָנֵי: ״תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה״, אַלְמָא: תְּמָרִים עֲדִיפִי.
human_translation: What are the circumstances If you say according to the value he ate a zuz and he paid a zuz what is May a blessing come upon him? He ate a zuz and paid a zuz . Rather, is it not in accordance with the measure he ate a se’a of dried figs worth one zuz , and he paid a se’a of dates worth four And it says: May a blessing come upon him. Apparently, dates are superior
llm_translation: How are the cases similar? If you say it is because of blood, that he ate from it with a coin and is repaying with a coin - what is "blessing shall come upon him"? He ate with a coin, he repays with a coin! Rather, is it not because of the measure, that he ate from it a large date pit's worth of coins, and is repaying with a large date pit's worth of dates - and it teaches: "blessing shall come upon him," indicating that dates are preferable.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: לְעוֹלָם דַּאֲכַל מִינֵּיהּ בְּזוּזָא, וְקָא מְשַׁלֵּם בְּזוּזָא. וּמַאי ״תָּבֹא עָלָיו בְּרָכָה״? דַּאֲכַל מִינֵּיהּ מִידֵּי דְּלָא קָפֵיץ עֲלֵיהּ זָבֵינָא, וְקָא מְשַׁלֵּם לֵיהּ מִידֵּי דְּקָפֵיץ עֲלֵיהּ זָבֵינָא.
human_translation: Abaye said to he actually ate a zuz and he paid a zuz And what May a blessing come upon him? For he ate something that buyers are not eager and he paid him something that buyers are eager
llm_translation: He said to him, Abaye: Always that he eats from it with a coin, and he is repaying with a coin. And what is "may blessing come upon him"? That he eats from it before the sellers jump upon it, and he is repaying it before the sellers jump upon it.

hebrew_text: שְׁתִיתָא — אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר פִּנְחָס: תְּרֵי שַׁרְגּוּשֵׁי. כִּיסָאנֵי — אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: תְּרֵי בוּנֵי דְּפוּמְבְּדִיתָא.
human_translation: shetita , Rav Aḥa bar Pineḥas said: Two large spoonfuls kisanei , Abaye said: Two Pumbeditan bunei ,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Shetiṯa — ʾamar Rav Aḥa bar Pinḥas: Terei shargušei. Kisānei — ʾamar Abbayei: Terei bunei dePumbedita. English translation: Two rows — Rav Aḥa bar Pinḥas said: Two rows of shingles. Baskets — Abbayei said: Two sons of Pumbedita.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, אֲמַרָה לִי אֵם: הָנֵי כִּסָאנֵי מְעַלּוּ לְלִיבָּא, וּמְבַטְּלִי מַחְשְׁבָתָא.
human_translation: Abaye said: Mother, told me: These roasted grains are good for the heart and drive away thoughts.
llm_translation: Abbaye said, "My mother told me: Those astrologers ascend to the heart, and nullify the thought."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר אַבָּיֵי, אֲמַרָה לִי אֵם: הַאי מַאן דְּאִית לֵיהּ חוּלְשָׁא דְּלִיבָּא, לַיְיתֵי בִּישְׂרָא דְּאַטְמָא יַמִּינָא דְּדִיכְרָא, וְלַיְיתֵי כַּבּוּיֵי דְרֵעִיתָא דְּנִיסָן, וְאִי לֵיכָּא כַּבּוּיֵי דְרֵעִיתָא — לַיְיתֵי סוּגְיָינֵי דַעֲרַבְתָּא, וְנִיכַבְּבֵיהּ וְנֵיכוּל, וְנִשְׁתֵּי בָּתְרֵיהּ חַמְרָא מַרְקָא.
human_translation: And Abaye said: Mother told me One who suffers from weakness of the heart should bring the meat of the right thigh of a ram, and bring the dung of grazing cattle from Nisan, and if there is no cattle dung he should bring willow twigs, and roast and eat and drink afterward diluted wine.
llm_translation: And Abaye said, his mother said to me: Whoever has a weak heart, let him bring the right ear of a male lamb, and let him bring the liver of a male lamb of the first year, and if he does not have the liver of a male lamb of the first year - let him bring the teeth of a wolf, grind them up, and drink them with red wine.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כׇּל שֶׁהוּא לִיפְתָּן, כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל בּוֹ. כֹּל שֶׁאֵינוֹ לִיפְתָּן, כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל הֵימֶנּוּ. בָּשָׂר חַי — כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל הֵימֶנּוּ. בָּשָׂר צָלִי, רַבָּה אָמַר: כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל בּוֹ, וְרַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר: כְּדֵי לֶאֱכוֹל הֵימֶנּוּ.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said Shmuel said: anything that serves as a relish enough to eat with it, And anything that is not a relish, enough to eat of it. raw meat enough to eat of it. Roasted meat Rabba said: Enough to eat with it. And Rav Yosef said: Enough to eat of it,
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: Anything that is for Yiftan, is sufficient to eat it. Anything that is not for Yiftan, is sufficient to eat from it. Live flesh - sufficient to eat from it. Roasted flesh, Rabba said: sufficient to eat it, and Rav Yosef said: sufficient to eat from it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ — דְּהָנֵי פָּרְסָאֵי אָכְלִי טַבְהָקִי בְּלָא נַהֲמָא! אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וּפָרְסָאֵי הֲווֹ רוּבָּא דְעָלְמָא?! וְהָתְנַן: בִּגְדֵי עֲנִיִּים לַעֲנִיִּים, בִּגְדֵי עֲשִׁירִים לַעֲשִׁירִים.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this For these Persians eat pieces of meat [ tabahakki ] without bread, Abaye said to him: But are the Persians a majority of the world? Didn’t we learn Clothing of the poor, poor people Clothing of the wealthy the wealthy.
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: From where do I know this? — That the Persians eat their bread without salt! Abaye said to him: And are the Persians the majority of the world?! But we learned: Clothing of the poor for the poor, clothing of the rich for the rich.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל בִּגְדֵי עֲשִׁירִים לַעֲנִיִּים — לָא.
human_translation: But the clothing of the wealthy not for the poor
llm_translation: But the garments of the wealthy to the poor - no.

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא: הָכָא לְחוּמְרָא וְהָכָא לְחוּמְרָא, וְהָתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: מְעָרְבִין לְחוֹלֶה וּלְזָקֵן כְּדֵי מְזוֹנוֹ. וּלְרַעַבְתָן, בִּסְעוּדָה בֵּינוֹנִית שֶׁל כׇּל אָדָם. קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: And if you say: here stringent, there stringent, Wasn’t it taught Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: One may establish an eiruv for an ill or elderly with food that is enough for him however, for a glutton, an average meal for the typical person? difficult.
llm_translation: And if you will say: here for stringency and here for stringency, and it was taught, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: We may mix wine for a sick person and for an elderly person for the amount of his sustenance. And for one who is hungry, with a regular meal of all people. This is difficult.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר הָכִי? וְהָתַנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: עוֹג מֶלֶךְ הַבָּשָׁן — פִּיתְחוֹ כִּמְלוֹאוֹ!
human_translation: Did Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar say this? Wasn’t it taught Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Og, king of the Bashan, opening as his full size?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And who said Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar the Kohen? And it was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: 'Og, king of Bashan - his mouth opened like a well!'" English translation:

hebrew_text: וְאַבָּיֵי: הָתָם הֵיכִי לֶיעְבֵּיד, הַדּוֹמֵי נְהַדְּמֵיהּ [וְנַפְּקֵיהּ]?!
human_translation: And Abaye There, what should we do? Should we cut into pieces and carry it out?
llm_translation: And Abbaye said: There, how is it done, that he should resemble him and go out?!

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: פְּלִיגִי רַבָּנַן עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר, אוֹ לָא? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: עוֹג מֶלֶךְ הַבָּשָׁן פִּיתְחוֹ בְּאַרְבָּעָה.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before Do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, or not? Come hear Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Og, king of the Bashan, an opening of four
llm_translation: He asked them: Do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar or not? Come and hear, for Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: "Og, king of Bashan, they opened him with four."

hebrew_text: הָתָם דְּאִיכָּא פְּתָחִים קְטַנִּים טוּבָא, וְאִיכָּא חַד דְּהָוֵי אַרְבָּעָה, דְּוַדַּאי כִּי קָא מְרַוַּח — בְּהָהוּא קָא מְרַוַּח.
human_translation: There, where there are many small openings, and there is one that is four with certainty that when one widens he will widen that
llm_translation: There, where there are small openings many, and there is one that is four, certainly when it is ventilated - in that it is ventilated.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִיָּיא בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר רַב: מְעָרְבִין בְּבָשָׂר חַי. אָמַר רַב שִׁימִי בַּר חִיָּיא: מְעָרְבִין בְּבֵיצִים חַיּוֹת. וְכַמָּה? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: אַחַת. סִינַי אָמַר: שְׁתַּיִם.
human_translation: Rav Ḥiyya bar Rav Ashi said that Rav said: One may establish an eiruv with raw meat Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya said: One may establish an eiruv with raw eggs. How many Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: One. Sinai, said: Two.
llm_translation: Rav Chiya bar Rav Ashe said in the name of Rav: One may mix with live flesh. Rav Shimi bar Chiya said: One may mix with live eggs. And how many? Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: One. Sinai said: Two.

hebrew_text: הַנּוֹדֵר מִן הַמָּזוֹן, מוּתָּר בַּמַּיִם כּוּ׳. מֶלַח וּמַיִם הוּא דְּלָא אִיקְּרִי מָזוֹן, הָא כׇּל מִילֵּי אִיקְּרִי מָזוֹן. לֵימָא תֶּיהְוֵי תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל. דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: אֵין מְבָרְכִין ״בּוֹרֵא מִינֵי מְזוֹנוֹת״ אֶלָּא עַל חֲמֵשֶׁת הַמִּינִין בִּלְבַד.
human_translation: One who vows that nourishment is permitted water It is salt and water are not considered nourishment, but all items are considered nourishment. Let us say this is a refutation of Rav and Shmuel. As it was Rav and Shmuel who both said: One only recites the blessing: Who creates kinds of nourishment, over the five species alone,
llm_translation: One who vows from food, permitted in water, salt and water, for it is not called food, but all things are called food. Let it be the preference of Rav and Shmuel. For Rav and Shmuel who both said: One does not recite "Who creates various kinds of foods" except on the five species alone.

hebrew_text: וְלָא אוֹתְבִינֵּיהּ חֲדָא זִימְנָא? לֵימָא תֶּיהְוֵי תְּיוּבְתַּיְיהוּ נָמֵי מֵהָא!
human_translation: Did we not refute on one occasion let us say there is a refutation of their from here as well.
llm_translation: And did they not understand it one time? Let it be that they will be better than him from this!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: בְּאוֹמֵר ״כׇּל הַזָּן עָלַי״. מַיִם וּמֶלַח הוּא דְּלָא זָיְינִי, הָא כׇּל מִילֵּי זָיְינִי.
human_translation: Rav Huna said: says: Anything that nourishes to me. it is water and salt as they do not nourish, but all items do nourish.
llm_translation: Rav Huna said: When one says, "All who feed me," it is water and salt that I do not feed on, for all other things I feed on.

hebrew_text: וְהָאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה: כִּי הֲוָה אָזֵילְנָא בָּתְרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְמֵיכַל פֵּירֵי דְּגִינּוֹסַר, כִּי הֲוֵינַן בֵּי מְאָה — הֲוָה מְנַקְּטִינַן לְכׇל חַד וְחַד עַשְׂרָה עַשְׂרָה. כִּי הֲוֵינַן בֵּי עַשְׂרָה — הֲוָה מְנַקְּטִינַן לְכׇל חַד וְחַד מְאָה מְאָה. וְכׇל מְאָה מִינַּיְיהוּ (לָא) הֲוֵי מַחֲזִיק לְהוּ צַנָּא בַּת תְּלָתָא סָאוֵי, וַהֲוָה אָכֵיל לְהוּ לְכוּלְּהוֹן, וְאָמַר: שְׁבוּעָתָא דְּלָא טְעִים לִי זִיּוּנָא! אֵימָא: ״מְזוֹנָא״.
human_translation: Didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say: When we were following Rabbi Yoḥanan to eat of the fruits of Genosar, when we were of a hundred each and every would take ten when we were of ten, each and every would take a hundred And each hundred of these could not fit into a three- se’a basket. And would eat them all and say: I swear that I have not tasted something that nourishes. Say sustaining food,
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: When we would go after Rabbi Yoḥanan’s daughter to eat the fish of Ginosar, when we were a group of one hundred, we would divide into groups of ten each. When we were a group of ten, we would divide into groups of one hundred each. And from all of them, we would not hold back for them a basket of three se’a, and he would eat for all of them, and he would say: 'A week that does not have a taste of rebuke is not a good week!' I say: 'Provision.'"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַב: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל כִּכָּר זוֹ״ — מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ. ״כִּכָּר זוֹ עָלַי״ — אֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Huna said Rav said: I swear that I shall not eat this loaf, one may establish an eiruv for him with it This loaf to me, one may not establish an eiruv for him with it,
llm_translation: Rav Huna said in the name of Rav: "If one takes an oath not to eat this loaf," we may mix it for him. "This loaf is upon me," we may not mix it for him.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הַנּוֹדֵר מִן הַכִּכָּר — מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ. מַאי לָאו, דְּאָמַר ״עָלַי״? לָא, דְּאָמַר ״זוֹ״.
human_translation: raises an objection one who vows from a loaf, one may establish an eiruv for him with it. What, is it not who said: to me? No, where he said: this
llm_translation: Challenger: One who vows from the loaf - we may mix it for him in it. What is the reason? Is it not because it says "upon me"? No, it is because it says "this."

hebrew_text: הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: אֵימָתַי, בִּזְמַן שֶׁאָמַר ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶטְעָמֶנָּה״.
human_translation: So too, it is reasonable as it was taught in the latter clause: When when one said: I swear that I shall not taste it.
llm_translation: Thus it was stated: for it is taught in the latter clause: When? At the time when he said, "A week that we will not taste it."

hebrew_text: אֲבָל אָמַר ״עָלַי״, מַאי? הָכִי נָמֵי דְּאֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ? אִי הָכִי, אַדְּתָנֵי ״כִּכָּר זוֹ הֶקְדֵּשׁ״ אֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מְעָרְבִין בַּהֶקְדֵּשׁוֹת — לִיפְלוֹג וְלִיתְנֵי בְּדִידַהּ: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים, דְּאָמַר ״זוֹ״, אֲבָל אָמַר ״עָלַי״ — אֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ!
human_translation: But he said: to me, what So too, one may not establish an eiruv for him with it. if so, Instead of teaching This loaf is consecrated one may not establish an eiruv for him with it, as one may not establish an eiruv with consecrated let him make distinction in the case itself In what is this statement said? one said: this But if one said: to me, one may not establish an eiruv for him with it.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But if he said "upon me," what is the law? Similarly, is it because we do not combine with it? If so, it was taught: "This loaf is holy," one does not combine with it, because we do not combine with holy items - to distinguish and to establish it by itself: in what case are these words said, that he said "this," but if he said "upon me" - one does not combine with it!

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ רַב הוּנָא: אֶלָּא מַאי, כֹּל הֵיכָא דְּאָמַר ״עָלַי״ מְעָרְבִין? קַשְׁיָא רֵישָׁא?
human_translation: Rav Huna said to you: Rather, what wherever said: to me, one may establish an eiruv a difficulty first clause
llm_translation: Rav Huna said to you: Rather, what is the reason that wherever it says "upon me" they mix the wine? Is the beginning difficult?

hebrew_text: חַסּוֹרֵי מִיחַסְּרָא, וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: הַנּוֹדֵר מִן הַכִּכָּר מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ, וַאֲפִילּוּ אָמַר ״עָלַי״ — נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר: שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אֶטְעָמֶנָּה.
human_translation: is incomplete, and it teaches the following: one who vows from a loaf, one may establish an eiruv for him with it. And even if one said: to me, it is as though he said: I swear that I shall not taste it.
llm_translation: The text reads: "Hasorei miChasera, vehachi katanei: HaNoder min haKikar mearvin lo bah, vaafilu amar 'alai' - na'asah ke'omer: Shevuah shel lo etamenna."

hebrew_text: מִכׇּל מָקוֹם קַשְׁיָא לְרַב הוּנָא! הוּא דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: ״שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁלֹּא אוֹכַל כִּכָּר זוֹ״ — מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ. ״כִּכָּר זוֹ עָלַי״ — אֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ.
human_translation: Nevertheless, difficulty according to Rav Huna. He stated in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer; as it was taught Rabbi Eliezer says: I swear that I shall not eat this loaf, one may establish an eiruv for him with it; This loaf to me, one may not establish an eiruv for him with it.
llm_translation: From every place, a difficulty for Rav Huna! He is the one who said like Rabbi Eliezer. As it was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says, "If one takes an oath 'I will not eat this loaf,' we may mix it for him. 'This loaf is upon me' - we do not mix it for him."

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הָכִי? וְהָתַנְיָא, זֶה הַכְּלָל: אָדָם אוֹסֵר עַצְמוֹ בְּאוֹכֶל — מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ. אוֹכֶל הַנֶּאְסָר לוֹ לְאָדָם — אֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: ״כִּכָּר זוֹ עָלַי״ — מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ. ״כִּכָּר זוֹ הֶקְדֵּשׁ״ — אֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בָּהּ, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מְעָרְבִין לוֹ בַּהֶקְדֵּשׁוֹת!
human_translation: Did Rabbi Eliezer say this? Wasn’t it taught This is the principle: a person prohibits himself from food, one may establish an eiruv for him with food was prohibited to a person, one may not establish an eiruv for him with it. Rabbi Eliezer says: This loaf to me, one may establish an eiruv for him with it. This loaf is consecrated one may not establish an eiruv for him with it, as one may not establish an eiruv for him with consecrated
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And who said thus, Rabbi Eliezer? And it was taught: This is the principle: If a person forbids himself with food - we may mix it for him. If the food is forbidden to a person - we do not mix it for him. Rabbi Eliezer says: "This loaf is upon me" - we may mix it for him. "This loaf is holy" - we do not mix it for him, because we do not mix for him with holy items!

hebrew_text: תְּרֵי תַנָּאֵי וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: two tanna’im according to Rabbi Eliezer.
llm_translation: Two Tannaim and the following of Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: מְעָרְבִין לַנָּזִיר בְּיַיִן כּוּ׳. מַתְנִיתִין דְּלָא כְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי. דְּתַנְיָא, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: אֵין מְעָרְבִין לַנָּזִיר בְּיַיִן וּלְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּתְרוּמָה, בֵּית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: מְעָרְבִין לַנָּזִיר בְּיַיִן וּלְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּתְרוּמָה. אָמְרוּ לָהֶן בֵּית הִלֵּל לְבֵית שַׁמַּאי: אִי אַתֶּם מוֹדִים
human_translation: One may establish an eiruv for a nazirite with wine The mishna not in accordance with Beit Shammai, as it was taught Beit Shammai say: One may not establish an eiruv for a nazirite with wine and for an Israelite with teruma . Beit Hillel say: One may establish an eiruv for a nazirite with wine and for an Israelite with teruma . Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: Do you not concede
llm_translation: We mix for the Nazirite with wine, etc. The Mishnah teaches not like Beit Shammai. As it was taught: Beit Shammai says: We do not mix for the Nazirite with wine, and for an Israelite with Terumah. Beit Hillel says: We mix for the Nazirite with wine, and for an Israelite with Terumah. Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: If you agree...

hebrew_text: שֶׁמְּעָרְבִין לְגָדוֹל בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים!
human_translation: that one may establish an eiruv for an adult on Yom Kippur,
llm_translation: They mix for the adult on the Day of Atonement!

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לָהֶן: אֲבָל! אָמְרוּ לָהֶן: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁמְּעָרְבִין לַגָּדוֹל בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים, כֵּן מְעָרְבִין לַנָּזִיר בְּיַיִן וּלְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּתְרוּמָה.
human_translation: said to them: Indeed [ aval ], said to them: Just as one may establish an eiruv for an adult on Yom Kippur, so one may establish an eiruv for a nazirite with wine and for an Israelite with teruma .
llm_translation: They said to them: But! They said to them: Just as we mix for the adult on Yom Kippur, so do we mix for the Nazirite with wine and for an Israelite with terumah.

hebrew_text: וּבֵית שַׁמַּאי: הָתָם — אִיכָּא סְעוּדָה הָרְאוּיָה מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם, הָכָא — לֵיכָּא סְעוּדָה הָרְאוּיָה מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם.
human_translation: And Beit Shammai There, there is a meal that was fit while it was still day, Here, there is no meal that was fit while it was still day,
llm_translation: House of Shammai: There — there is a meal appropriate from midday, here — there is not a meal appropriate from midday.

hebrew_text: כְּמַאן? דְּלָא כַּחֲנַנְיָה. דְּתַנְיָא, חֲנַנְיָה אוֹמֵר: כׇּל עַצְמָן שֶׁל בֵּית שַׁמַּאי לֹא הָיוּ מוֹדִים בְּעֵירוּב עַד שֶׁיּוֹצִיא מִטָּתוֹ וְכׇל כְּלֵי תַּשְׁמִישָׁיו לְשָׁם.
human_translation: In accordance with whose not in accordance with Ḥananya, as it was taught Ḥananya says: The whole of Beit Shammai, they did not concede to joining until he carries out his bed and his utensils to there,
llm_translation: As whom? That is not like Chananya. For it was taught: Chananya says, "All the bones of Beit Shammai did not agree to an eruv until he would take out his bed, and all his utensils for use to there."

hebrew_text: כְּמַאן אָזְלָא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: עֵירַב בִּשְׁחוֹרִים לֹא יֵצֵא בִּלְבָנִים, בִּלְבָנִים לֹא יֵצֵא בִּשְׁחוֹרִים. כְּמַאן? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: חֲנַנְיָה הִיא, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי.
human_translation: In accordance with whose is that was taught one established an eiruv in black he may not go out in white in white, he may not go out in black. According to whose Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It is Ḥananya, and in accordance with Beit Shammai.
llm_translation: As to where did he go? This is what was taught: One may not go out with black shoes into white shoes, nor with white shoes into black shoes. As to where? Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: It is regarding Chananya, in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai.

hebrew_text: וְלַחֲנַנְיָה, בִּשְׁחוֹרִים הוּא דְּלֹא יֵצֵא, הָא בִּלְבָנִים יֵצֵא? הָאָמַר עַד שֶׁיּוֹצִיא מִטָּתוֹ וּכְלֵי תַּשְׁמִישָׁיו לְשָׁם! הָכִי קָאָמַר: עֵירַב בִּלְבָנִים וְהוּצְרַךְ לִשְׁחוֹרִים, אַף בִּלְבָנִים לֹא יֵצֵא. כְּמַאן? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: חֲנַנְיָה הִיא, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי.
human_translation: And according to Ḥananya, with black he may not go out, but in white he may go out? Didn’t say until one carries out his bed and his utensils this is what it said: one established an eiruv in white and he needed black he may not go out even in white In accordance with whose Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It is Ḥananya, and in accordance with Beit Shammai.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And Chananya, in the white garments he is not allowed to go out, but in the white garments he may go out? This is what he said: Until he removes his bed and his utensils to there! This is what he meant: If he mixed in white garments and he needs black garments, even in white garments he may not go out. According to whom? Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: This is Chananya, in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai.

hebrew_text: סוֹמְכוֹס אוֹמֵר בְּחוּלִּין. וְאִילּוּ לַנָּזִיר בְּיַיִן לָא פְּלִיג, מַאי טַעְמָא — אֶפְשָׁר דְּמִתְּשִׁיל אַנְּזִירוּתֵיהּ.
human_translation: Summakhos says: with non-sacred But a nazirite with wine, does not disagree. What is the reason can ask his nazirite status,
