human_translation: What is the reason the entrance that is exclusively his is preferable to him.
llm_translation: What is the reason? Because at the outset he joins it, at that moment it is pleasing to him.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: פָּתוּחַ לְקַרְפֵּף, מַהוּ? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר אַמֵּי מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּאוּלְפָנָא:
human_translation: a dilemma was raised before opens into an enclosure what is Rav Naḥman bar Ami said, citing a tradition [ mishmei de’ulpana ]
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: If it is open to the roof, what is the law? Rav Nachman bar Ammi said in the name of Ulfana:

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ פָּתוּחַ לְקַרְפֵּף.
human_translation: Even opens into an enclosure,
llm_translation: Even if it is open to the ceiling.

hebrew_text: רַבָּה וְרַב יוֹסֵף דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: גּוֹי בֵּית סָאתַיִם — אוֹסֵר, יוֹתֵר מִבֵּית סָאתַיִם — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: Rabba and Rav Yosef who both say: a gentile, two beit se’a he renders it prohibited greater than two beit se’a , he does not render it prohibited
llm_translation: Rabba and Rav Yosef both said: A non-Jew within the area of two se'ahs prohibits the area for tithing purposes, more than two se'ahs does not prohibit.

hebrew_text: וְיִשְׂרָאֵל בֵּית סָאתַיִם — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: a Jew, two beit se’a he does not render it prohibited
llm_translation: "And Yisrael Beit Sa'ataim - he does not prohibit."

hebrew_text: יוֹתֵר מִבֵּית סָאתַיִם — אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: greater than two beit se’a , he renders it prohibited
llm_translation: More than two se'ahs - prohibited.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבָא בַּר חַקְלַאי מֵרַב הוּנָא: פָּתוּחַ לְקַרְפֵּף מַהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הֲרֵי אָמְרוּ בֵּית סָאתַיִם — אוֹסֵר, יוֹתֵר מִבֵּית סָאתַיִם — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: Rava bar Ḥaklai raised a dilemma before Rav Huna: opens into an enclosure, what is said to him: They have said two beit se’a renders it prohibited more than two beit se’a , he does not render it prohibited
llm_translation: Rava son of Hakhla'i asked Rav Huna: "If it is open to a courtyard, what is the law?" He said to him: "Behold, they said a Beit Sa'atayim - it prohibits, more than a Beit Sa'atayim - it does not prohibit."

hebrew_text: אָמַר עוּלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: קַרְפֵּף יוֹתֵר מִבֵּית סָאתַיִם שֶׁלֹּא הוּקַּף לְדִירָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ כּוֹר וַאֲפִילּוּ כּוֹרַיִים — הַזּוֹרֵק לְתוֹכוֹ חַיָּיב. מַאי טַעְמָא, מְחִיצָה הִיא, אֶלָּא שֶׁמְחוּסֶּרֶת דָּיוֹרִין.
human_translation: Ulla said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: an enclosure greater than two beit se’a that was not surrounded for residence, even kor , and even two kor , one who throws into it is liable What is the reason is a partition. except that it is lacking residents,
llm_translation: Ula said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: A courtyard more than two Beit Sa'at that was not enclosed for a dwelling, even if it is a pit or even two pits - one who throws into it is liable. What is the reason? It is considered a partition, but lacking in walls.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב הוּנָא בַּר חִינָּנָא: סֶלַע שֶׁבַּיָּם גָּבוֹהַּ עֲשָׂרָה וְרוֹחַב אַרְבָּעָה — אֵין מְטַלְטְלִין לֹא מִן תּוֹכוֹ לַיָּם וְלֹא מִן הַיָּם לְתוֹכוֹ. פָּחוֹת מִכָּאן — מְטַלְטְלִין. עַד כַּמָּה — עַד בֵּית סָאתַיִם.
human_translation: Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana raised an objection a rock the sea ten high and four wide, one not carry from it to the sea or from the sea to it is smaller than this, one carry How large up to two beit se’a .
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Huna son of Chinena asked: A rock in the sea, ten high and four wide - one may not move it neither from its place to the sea nor from the sea to its place. Less than this - one may move it. Until how much - until two se'ahs.

hebrew_text: אַהֵיָיא? אִילֵּימָא אַסֵּיפָא — בֵּית סָאתַיִם, טְפֵי לָא? וְהָא מִכַּרְמְלִית לְכַרְמְלִית קָא מְטַלְטֵל.
human_translation: To which If you say to the latter clause, two beit se’a , no more Wouldn’t he be carrying from one karmelit to another,
llm_translation: Ahayya? Ileima asseifa - Beit Sa'ataim, tefei la? Veha mikarmelit lekarmelit ka metaltel.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו אַרֵישָׁא, וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: סֶלַע שֶׁבַּיָּם גָּבוֹהַּ עֲשָׂרָה וְרוֹחַב אַרְבָּעָה — אֵין מְטַלְטְלִין לֹא מִתּוֹכוֹ לַיָּם וְלֹא מִן הַיָּם לְתוֹכוֹ. וְעַד כַּמָּה — עַד בֵּית סָאתַיִם, הָא יָתֵר מִבֵּית סָאתַיִם — מְטַלְטְלִין. אַלְמָא כַּרְמְלִית הִיא, תְּיוּבְתָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן!
human_translation: Rather, is it not to the first clause and this is it is saying: a rock the sea ten high and four wide, one may not carry from it to the sea or from the sea to it, And how large Up to two beit se’a . But greater than two beit se’a , one carry. Apparently, is a karmelit a conclusive refutation of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
llm_translation: Rather, it is not the first case, and thus he says: "A rock in the sea, ten cubits high and four cubits wide - one may not move it neither from within to the sea nor from the sea to within. And until where - until two Sa'ahs, more than two Sa'ahs - one may move it. This implies that it is like a Carmelit, the subsidiary of Rabbi Yochanan!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַאן דְּלָא יָדַע תָּרוֹצֵי מַתְנְיָיתָא — תְּיוּבְתָּא מוֹתֵיב לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן. לְעוֹלָם אַרֵישָׁא, וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: הָא בְּתוֹכוֹ — מְטַלְטְלִין. וְעַד כַּמָּה — עַד בֵּית סָאתַיִם.
human_translation: Rava said: one who does not know how to explain mishnayot raises refutations against Rabbi Yoḥanan, Actually, to the first clause, and this is it is saying: but within it, one carry, how large Up to two beit se’a .
llm_translation: Rava said: One who does not know the reasoning of the Mishnah - a student raises an objection to Rabbi Yochanan. Always start with the first clause, and thus he says: "This law applies when it is within it - one may move it. And until when - up to two se'ahs."

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם אַרֵישָׁא, הֵן אָמְרוּ וְהֵן אָמְרוּ.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said Actually, to the first clause, they said and they said
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: Always first, they said and they said.

hebrew_text: הֵן אָמְרוּ: קַרְפֵּף יָתֵר מִבֵּית סָאתַיִם שֶׁלֹּא הוּקַּף לְדִירָה — אֵין מְטַלְטְלִין בּוֹ אֶלָּא בְּאַרְבַּע אַמּוֹת. וְהֵן אָמְרוּ: אֵין מְטַלְטְלִין מֵרְשׁוּת הַיָּחִיד לְכַרְמְלִית.
human_translation: They said an enclosure greater than two beit se’a that was not enclosed for one carry only four cubits, And they said one not carry from a private domain to a karmelit .
llm_translation: Behold they said: A beam more than two Sa'ahs that was not encircled for a dwelling - one may only carry within it for four cubits. And behold they said: One may not carry from a private domain to a Carmelite.

hebrew_text: בֵּית סָאתַיִם דְּשָׁרֵי לְטַלְטוֹלֵי בְּכוּלֵּיהּ, אָסְרִי רַבָּנַן לְטַלְטוֹלֵי לֹא מִן הַיָּם לְתוֹכוֹ וְלֹא מִתּוֹכוֹ לַיָּם. מַאי טַעְמָא, רְשׁוּת הַיָּחִיד גְּמוּרָה הִיא.
human_translation: two beit se’a , that it is permitted to carry on all of it, the Sages prohibited carrying from the sea to it and from it to the sea. What is the reason is a full-fledged private domain,
llm_translation: House of two se'ahs that are permitted to move in its entirety, the Rabbis prohibited moving it, not from the sea into it and not from it into the sea. What is the reason? It is considered a complete private domain.

hebrew_text: יָתֵר מִבֵּית סָאתַיִם, דְּאָסוּר לְטַלְטוֹלֵי בְּכוּלֵּיהּ, שָׁרוּ רַבָּנַן לְטַלְטוֹלֵי מִתּוֹכוֹ לַיָּם וּמִן הַיָּם לְתוֹכוֹ. מַאי טַעְמָא? דִּלְמָא אָמְרִי: רְשׁוּת הַיָּחִיד גְּמוּרָה הִיא, וְאָתֵי לְטַלְטוֹלֵי בְּכוּלֵּיהּ.
human_translation: larger than two beit se’a , that it is prohibited to carry on all of it the Sages permitted carrying from the sea to it and from it to the sea. What is the reason perhaps say it is a proper private domain, and they would come to carry on all of it.
llm_translation: Excess of two Beit Sa'at, that it is forbidden to carry out all of it, the Rabbis permitted to carry out from its midst to the sea and from the sea to its midst. What is the reason? Perhaps they say: A private domain is completely enclosed, and one may come to carry out all of it.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי שְׁנָא? תּוֹכוֹ שְׁכִיחַ. מִתּוֹכוֹ לַיָּם וּמִן הַיָּם לְתוֹכוֹ — לָא שְׁכִיחַ.
human_translation: And what is the difference within is common, from it to the sea and from the sea to it is not common.
llm_translation: And what is the difference? Its inside is common. From its inside to the sea, and from the sea to its inside - it is not common.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא יָנוֹקָא דְּאִשְׁתְּפִיךְ חַמִּימֵיהּ. אֲמַר לְהוּ רַבָּה: נַיְיתוֹ לֵיהּ חַמִּימֵי מִגּוֹ בֵּיתַאי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְהָא לָא עָרְבִינַן.
human_translation: a certain baby whose warm water, spilled. Rabba said to them: Let them bring warm water for him from my house. Abaye said to him: But we did not establish an eiruv
llm_translation: That young man who was drinking his wine. Rabba said to him: "Bring him more wine from the wine cellar." Abaye said to him: "But we have not yet mixed it."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: נִסְמוֹךְ אַשִּׁיתּוּף. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָא לָא שַׁתְּפִינַן. נֵימְרוּ לֵיהּ לְגוֹי לַיְתֵי לֵיהּ.
human_translation: said to him: Let us rely on the merging said to him: But we did not establish a merging let them instruct a gentile to bring for him,
llm_translation: He said to him: "Let us join together." He said to him: "No, we should not join together." They said to him: "Let the Gentile come and join with him."

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: בְּעַי לְאוֹתֹבֵיהּ לְמָר, וְלָא שַׁבְקַן רַב יוֹסֵף, דְּאָמַר רַב [יוֹסֵף אָמַר רַב] כָּהֲנָא: כִּי הֲוֵינַן בֵּי רַב יְהוּדָה, הֲוָה אֲמַר לַן: בִּדְאוֹרָיְיתָא — מוֹתְבִינַן תְּיוּבְתָּא וַהֲדַר עָבְדִינַן מַעֲשֶׂה, בִּדְרַבָּנַן — עָבְדִינַן מַעֲשֶׂה וַהֲדַר מוֹתְבִינַן תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: Abaye said: I wanted to raise an objection against the Master, but Rav Yosef would not let me Rav Yosef said Rav Kahana said: When we were in Rav Yehuda’s house, he would say to us a Torah law, we raise objections and then we perform an act, with regard to rabbinic laws, we perform an act and then raise objections.
llm_translation: Abaye said: He needs to give it to his master, and Rav Yosef did not leave it, as Rav Yosef said Rav Kahana said: When we were in the house of Rav Yehuda, he used to say to us: In matters of Torah, we first understand the reasoning and then perform the action; in matters of Rabbinic law, we first perform the action and then understand the reasoning.

hebrew_text: לְבָתַר הָכִי אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי בָּעֵית לְאוֹתֹבֵיהּ לְמָר? אֲמַר [לֵיהּ: דְּתַנְיָא]: הַזָּאָה שְׁבוּת, וַאֲמִירָה לְגוֹי שְׁבוּת.
human_translation: Afterward, said to What objection did you wish to raise against the Master, said to him: As it was taught Sprinkling a rabbinic decree And telling a gentile a rabbinic decree.
llm_translation: Afterwards, he said to him: "What do you need for your master's sign?" He said to him: "As it was taught: 'The gold is returned, and the saying is returned to its owner.'"

hebrew_text: מָה הַזָּאָה שְׁבוּת, וְאֵינָהּ דּוֹחָה אֶת הַשַּׁבָּת. אַף אֲמִירָה לְגוֹי שְׁבוּת, וְאֵינָהּ דּוֹחָה אֶת הַשַּׁבָּת.
human_translation: Just as sprinkling rabbinic decree and does not override Shabbat, so too, telling a gentile rabbinic decree and does not override Shabbat.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: What is the case of a non-Jew's rest that does not override the Sabbath? Similarly, the declaration of rest by a non-Jew does not override the Sabbath.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְלָא שָׁנֵי לָךְ בֵּין שְׁבוּת דְּאִית בֵּיהּ מַעֲשֶׂה לִשְׁבוּת דְּלֵית בֵּיהּ מַעֲשֶׂה? דְּהָא מָר לָא אֲמַר לְגוֹי: זִיל אַחֵים.
human_translation: said to him: But do you not differentiate between a rabbinic decree that involves an action and a rabbinic decree that does not involve an action? As the Master, did not say to the gentile: Go and heat
llm_translation: He said to him: "And is it not different for you between a case where there is an action in it and a case where there is no action in it? For the Master did not say to a non-Jew: 'Go, brothers.'"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבָּה בַּר רַב חָנָן לְאַבָּיֵי: מְבוֹאָה דְּאִית בֵּיהּ תְּרֵי גַּבְרֵי רַבְרְבֵי כְּרַבָּנַן, לָא לֶיהֱוֵי בֵּיהּ לָא עֵירוּב וְלֹא שִׁיתּוּף?! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי נַעֲבֵיד? מָר, לָאו אוֹרְחֵיהּ. אֲנָא, טְרִידְנָא בְּגִירְסַאי. אִינְהוּ, לָא מַשְׁגְּחִי.
human_translation: Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye: an alleyway that contains two such great people as the Sages there could be neither an eiruv nor a merging said to him: What should we do? the Master, is not his manner myself, I am busy with my studies they, do not attend to
llm_translation: Rabah bar Rav Hana said to Abbaye: "If a courtyard has two residents like Rabbanan, should it not be fit for neither an eruv nor partnership?" He said to him: "What can we do? Master, it is not his way. I am engaged in my studies. They are not concerned."

hebrew_text: וְאִי אַקְנִי לְהוּ פִּיתָּא בְּסַלָּא — כֵּיוָן דְּאִי בָּעוּ לַהּ מִינַּאי וְלָא אֶפְשָׁר לִיתְּבַהּ נִהֲלַיְיהוּ, בָּטֵיל שִׁיתּוּף.
human_translation: And if I were to transfer to bread in basket, since if they would want from me it would be impossible to give it to them merging be invalid.
llm_translation: And if I acquire for them bread in a basket - since if they come to him with kinds and it is not possible to sit them down, the partnership is annulled.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: אֶחָד מִבְּנֵי מָבוֹי שֶׁבִּיקֵּשׁ יַיִן וָשֶׁמֶן, וְלֹא נָתְנוּ לוֹ — בָּטֵל הַשִּׁתּוּף.
human_translation: As it was taught one of the residents of an alleyway requested wine or oil and they did not give him the merging is invalid.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: One of the residents of a courtyard who sought wine and oil, and they did not give it to him - he annuls the partnership.

hebrew_text: וְנַקְנֵי לְהוּ מָר רְבִיעֲתָא דְחַלָּא בְּחָבִיתָא. תַּנְיָא, אֵין מִשְׁתַּתְּפִין בָּאוֹצָר.
human_translation: But let the Master transfer to them a quarter- of vinegar in barrels; It was taught One may not use storeroom for a merging
llm_translation: And they bought for him, Master Revi'ata of vinegar in a barrel. It was taught: They do not share in the treasury.

hebrew_text: וְהָא תַּנְיָא מִשְׁתַּתְּפִין! אָמַר רַב אוֹשַׁעְיָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא — בֵּית שַׁמַּאי, הָא — בֵּית הִלֵּל.
human_translation: Wasn’t it taught One may use for a merging Rav Oshaya said: not difficult. This Beit Shammai. that Beit Hillel.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And there is a teaching that they participate together! Rav Oshaya said: It is not difficult, here - Beit Shammai, here - Beit Hillel."

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: הַמֵּת בַּבַּיִת, וְלוֹ פְּתָחִים הַרְבֵּה — כּוּלָּן טְמֵאִין.
human_translation: As we learned a corpse is in a house, has many entrances, they are all ritually impure.
llm_translation: We have learned in a Mishnah: One who dies in a house, and there are many openings in it — all of them are rendered impure.

hebrew_text: נִפְתַּח אֶחָד מֵהֶן — הוּא טָמֵא, וְכוּלָּן טְהוֹרִין. חִישֵּׁב לְהוֹצִיאוֹ בְּאֶחָד מֵהֶן, אוֹ בַּחַלּוֹן שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ אַרְבָּעָה עַל אַרְבָּעָה — מַצִּיל עַל כׇּל הַפְּתָחִים כּוּלָּן.
human_translation: if one of them was open, that is ritually impure, while all of the others are ritually pure. one decided to remove through one of or through a window that is four by four it saves all of the entrances
llm_translation: One of them opened - he is impure, and all of them are pure. If he intended to remove it through one of them, or through a window that is four by four handbreadths - he saves all the openings.

hebrew_text: בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: וְהוּא שֶׁחִישֵּׁב עַד שֶׁלֹּא יָמוּת הַמֵּת. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: אַף מִשֶּׁיָּמוּת הַמֵּת.
human_translation: Beit Shammai say: This if he had decided before the person died, But Beit Hillel say: even after the person had died,
llm_translation: House of Shammai says: "And he should sit until the deceased dies." And House of Hillel says: "Even after the deceased dies."

hebrew_text: הָהוּא יָנוֹקָא דְּאִישְׁתְּפוּךְ חַמִּימֵיהּ, אֲמַר לְהוּ רָבָא: נִישַׁיְּילַהּ לְאִימֵּיהּ אִי צְרִיכָא — נַחֵים לֵיהּ גּוֹי אַגַּב אִימֵּיהּ.
human_translation: a certain baby whose warm water, spilled. Rava said to Let us ask the mother. If necessary let a gentile heat for indirectly, through his mother.
llm_translation: That young man who overturned his mother's pot of hot water, Rava said to them: If he needs it - he should appease her with it, for it is written, "Honor your father and your mother."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב מְשַׁרְשְׁיָא לְרָבָא: אִימֵּיהּ קָא אָכְלָה תַּמְרֵי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֵימוֹר, תּוּנְבָּא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא דְּנָקֵט לַהּ.
human_translation: Rav Mesharshiya said to Rava: mother she is eating dates. said to him: say it was merely a ravenous hunger that had seized her,
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Mesharshaya said to Rava: His mother ate dates. He said to him: Say, it is a common phenomenon in the world that it is detrimental to her.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא יָנוֹקָא דְּאִישְׁתְּפוּךְ חַמִּימֵיהּ, אֲמַר לְהוּ רָבָא: פַּנּוּ לִי מָאנֵי מִבֵּי גַבְרֵי לְבֵי נְשֵׁי, וְאֵיזִיל וְאִיתֵּיב הָתָם וְאֶיבַטֵּיל לְהוּ הָא חָצֵר.
human_translation: a certain baby whose warm water, spilled. Rava, said to Clear away my belongings from the men’s chamber, to the women’s chamber, And I will go and sit there, and I will renounce this courtyard in favor of
llm_translation: That young man who was playing with his mother's dates, Rava said to them: Turn your face away from the house of men to the house of women, and I will go and sit there and nullify the courtyard for them.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא לְרָבָא, וְהָאָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אֵין בִּיטּוּל רְשׁוּת מֵחָצֵר לְחָצֵר?! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֲנָא כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סְבִירָא לִי, דְּאָמַר: יֵשׁ בִּיטּוּל מֵחָצֵר לְחָצֵר.
human_translation: Ravina said to Rava: Didn’t Shmuel say: There is no renunciation of rights from one courtyard to another. said to him: I hold in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said: There is renouncing of rights from one courtyard to another.
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rava, and Shmuel said: Is there no nullification of domain from courtyard to courtyard?! He said to him: I, like Rabbi Yochanan, hold, for he said: There is nullification from courtyard to courtyard.

hebrew_text: וְאִי לָא סָבַר לַהּ מָר כִּשְׁמוּאֵל
human_translation: But if the Master does not hold in accordance with Shmuel,
llm_translation: And if not, he does not hold like Master Kishmael.

hebrew_text: נִיתֵּיב מָר בְּדוּכְתֵּיהּ, וְנִיבַטֵּיל לְהוּ לְדִידְהוּ, וְנִיהְדְּרוּ אִינְהוּ וְנִיבַטְּלוּ לֵיהּ לְמָר, דְּהָא אָמַר רַב: מְבַטְּלִין, וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין.
human_translation: let the Master remain in his place, and renounce in favor And then, let them renounce in favor of the Master, As Rav said: may renounce and may then renounce
llm_translation: The master cleared his path, and he looked at them, and they were embarrassed and looked at the master, for Rav said: they nullify, and they nullify again.

hebrew_text: אֲנָא בְּהָא כִּשְׁמוּאֵל סְבִירָא לִי, דְּאָמַר: אֵין מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין.
human_translation: In this I hold in accordance with Shmuel, who said: One not renounce and then renounce
llm_translation: I, in this matter, like Shmuel, hold, for he said: we do not nullify and return and nullify.

hebrew_text: וְלָאו חַד טַעְמָא הוּא? מַאי טַעְמָא אֵין מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין — לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּכֵיוָן דְּבַטְּלֵיהּ לִרְשׁוּתֵיהּ, אִסְתַּלַּק לֵיהּ מֵהָכָא לִגְמָרֵי, וְהָוֵה לֵיהּ כְּבֶן חָצֵר אַחֶרֶת, וְאֵין בִּיטּוּל רְשׁוּת מֵחָצֵר לְחָצֵר. מָר נָמֵי, לָא נִיבַטֵּיל.
human_translation: Isn’t the reason one What is the reason one not renounce and then renounce Is it not because since he renounced his rights completely removed himself from here, and he is like the resident of a different courtyard, and there is no renouncing of rights from one courtyard to another? the Master should likewise not renounce
llm_translation: And is it not one reason? What is the reason? We do not nullify and return and nullify - not because since he nullified it to his domain, it has completely departed from here, and it is to him like a son of another courtyard, and nullification of domain from courtyard to courtyard does not occur. Mar Nami, it is not nullified.

hebrew_text: הָתָם הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא: כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לֶיהֱוֵי מִלְּתָא דְּרַבָּנַן כְּחוּכָא וְאִטְלוּלָא.
human_translation: There, this is the rationale So that the words of the Sages should not be of laughter and mockery.
llm_translation: There the same reason: how not to be a matter of the Rabbis as a joke and a mockery.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא, רַב אָמַר: מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֵין מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין.
human_translation: the matter itself, Rav said: may renounce and then may renounce And Shmuel said: One not renounce and then renounce
llm_translation: The body, Rav said: we nullify and return and nullify, and Shmuel said: we do not nullify and return and nullify.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל בִּפְלוּגְתָּא דְּרַבָּנַן וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר קָא מִיפַּלְגִי.
human_translation: Let us say Rav and Shmuel disagree about the dispute as the Rabbis and Rabbi Eliezer.
llm_translation: Let us say, Rav and Shmuel in the dispute of the Sages, and Rabbi Eliezer is differing.

hebrew_text: דְּרַב דְּאָמַר כְּרַבָּנַן וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: that Rav stated in accordance with the Rabbis, And Shmuel stated in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer.
llm_translation: Regarding Rav who said like Rabbanan, and Shmuel who said like Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ רַב, אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הָתָם הַמְּבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת חֲצֵירוֹ — רְשׁוּת בֵּיתוֹ בִּיטֵּל, מִשּׁוּם דִּבְבַיִת בְּלָא חָצֵר לָא דָּיְירִי אִינָשֵׁי. אֲבָל לְעִנְיַן אִיסְתַּלּוֹקֵי, מִי אָמַר?
human_translation: Rav said to you: What I said is even in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Eliezer stated there, one who renounces his rights to his courtyard renounces his rights to his house, only because people do not live in a house without a courtyard, However, with regard to removed did he state
llm_translation: Rav said to you: I, who say even according to Rabbi Eliezer: Until here Rabbi Eliezer did not say. There, one who nullifies his courtyard - nullifies his house, because people do not dwell in a house without a courtyard. But regarding the matter of detachment, who said?

hebrew_text: וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ כְּרַבָּנַן, עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן הָתָם אֶלָּא מַאי דְּבַטֵּיל בַּטֵּיל, וּדְלָא בַּטֵּיל לָא בַּטֵּיל. אֲבָל מַאי דְּבַטֵּיל — מִיהָא אִיסְתַּלַּק לִגְמָרֵי.
human_translation: And Shmuel said: What I said is even in accordance with the Rabbis. The Rabbis stated only there, That which he has renounced, is renounced; and he has not renounced, is not renounced. However, that which he has renounced, he has removed himself completely.
llm_translation: Samuel said: I say, even like Rabbanan, until here not said Rabbanan there rather what nullifies nullifies, and what does not nullify does not nullify. But what nullifies - from it completely departs.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר חָנָא אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת, כְּתַנָּאֵי: מִי שֶׁנָּתַן רְשׁוּתוֹ, וְהוֹצִיא, בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד — אוֹסֵר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּמֵזִיד — אוֹסֵר, בְּשׁוֹגֵג — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Ḥana said Rav Sheshet said: like tanna’im . one gave his rights and he carried out whether unwittingly, or intentionally, he renders prohibited the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: intentionally, he renders prohibited unwittingly, he does not render prohibited
llm_translation: Rav Ahah bar Hanah said in the name of Rav Sheshet, as it was taught in a Baraita: One who has given his permission and then retracts, whether it was done unintentionally or intentionally — he forbids it, according to the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: If it was done intentionally — he forbids it, if it was done unintentionally — he does not forbid it.

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו, בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי: דְּמָר סָבַר מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין, וּמַר סָבַר אֵין מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין.
human_translation: What, is it not that they disagree this: One Sage, holds one renounce and then renounce one Sage, holds may not renounce and then renounce
llm_translation: What is the reason that they do not agree? For Mar holds that we nullify and repeat, and nullify again, while Mar holds that we do not nullify and repeat, and nullify.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַחָא בַּר תַּחְלִיפָא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא אֵין מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין, וְהָכָא בְּקָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד קָא מִיפַּלְגִי. מָר סָבַר: קָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד, וּמָר סָבַר: לֹא קָנְסוּ שׁוֹגֵג אַטּוּ מֵזִיד.
human_translation: Rav Aḥa bar Taḥalifa said in the name of Rava: No, everyone agrees may not renounce and then renounce And here, they disagree penalize unwitting due to intentional One Sage, holds they penalized unwitting due to intentional And one Sage, holds they did not penalize unwitting due to intentional
llm_translation: Rav Acha bar Tachlifa said in the name of Rava: No, for in all other cases, they do not nullify and then nullify again, but here, they nullify due to an unintentional transgression, and then they nullify due to an intentional transgression. One Sage holds: They nullify due to an unintentional transgression, and then due to an intentional transgression, and the other Sage holds: They did not nullify due to an unintentional transgression, and then due to an intentional transgression.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל בִּפְלוּגְתָּא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר וְרַבָּנַן קָא מִיפַּלְגִי.
human_translation: Rav Ashi, said: Rav and Shmuel disagree in the dispute as Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis.
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: Rav and Shmuel in the dispute of Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis are divided.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּצַדּוּקִי אֶחָד שֶׁהָיָה דָּר עִמָּנוּ. צַדּוּקִי מַאן דְּכַר שְׁמֵיהּ?
human_translation: Rabban Gamliel said: an incident involving a certain Sadducee who lived with us A Sadducee; who mentioned his name?
llm_translation: Rabban Gamliel said: There was an incident with a certain Sadducee who lived among us. Who remembers the name of that Sadducee?

hebrew_text: חַסּוֹרֵי מִיחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: צַדּוּקִי הֲרֵי הוּא כְּגוֹי, וְרַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: צַדּוּקִי אֵינוֹ כְּגוֹי. וְאָמַר רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּצַדּוּקִי אֶחָד שֶׁהָיָה דָּר עִמָּנוּ בְּמָבוֹי בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, וְאָמַר לָנוּ אַבָּא: מַהֲרוּ וְהוֹצִיאוּ אֶת הַכֵּלִים לַמָּבוֹי, עַד שֶׁלֹּא יוֹצִיא וְיֶאֱסֹר עֲלֵיכֶם.
human_translation: is incomplete. and this it is teaching: a Sadducee is like a gentile, and Rabban Gamliel says: a Sadducee is not like a gentile. And Rabban Gamliel said: an incident involving a certain Sadducee who lived with us in alleyway in Jerusalem, and Father said to us: Hurry and take out utensils to the alleyway before takes out he would render it prohibited for you
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Hasorei michasra ve'hachi katanei: Tzaduki harei hu kegoy, ve'Rabban Gamliel omer: Tzaduki einu kegoy. Ve'amar Rabban Gamliel: Ma'aseh be'Tzaduki echad she'haya dar imanu be'mavoi bi'Yerushalayim, ve'amar lanu Aba: Maheru ve'hotzi'u et ha'kelim la'mavoi, ad she'lo yotzi ve'ye'esor aleichem." I will now provide the word-for-word English translation: "Lacking from lacking and thus it is taught: Sadducee behold he as a gentile, and Rabban Gamliel says: Sadducee is not as a gentile. And Rabban Gamliel said: There was an incident with one Sadducee who was residing with us in a courtyard in Jerusalem, and he said to us: Hurry and bring out the vessels to the courtyard, until he does not bring out and forbid upon you."

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: הַדָּר עִם הַנׇּכְרִי, צַדּוּקִי, וּבַיְתּוֹסִי — הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ אוֹסְרִין עָלָיו. (רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: צַדּוּקִי וּבַיְתּוֹסִי אֵינָן אוֹסְרִין.) וּמַעֲשֶׂה בְּצַדּוּקִי אֶחָד שֶׁהָיָה דָּר עִם רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל בְּמָבוֹי בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, וְאָמַר לָהֶם רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל לְבָנָיו: בָּנַי, מַהֲרוּ וְהוֹצִיאוּ מַה שֶּׁאַתֶּם מוֹצִיאִין וְהַכְנִיסוּ מַה שֶּׁאַתֶּם מַכְנִיסִין, עַד שֶׁלֹּא יוֹצִיא הַתּוֹעֵב הַזֶּה וְיֶאֱסֹר עֲלֵיכֶם, שֶׁהֲרֵי בִּיטֵּל רְשׁוּתוֹ לָכֶם, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: And wasn’t it taught one lives with a gentile, a Sadducee, or a Boethusian they render prohibited him. Rabban Gamliel says: A Sadducee or a Boethusian do not prohibit an incident involving a certain Sadducee who lived with Rabban Gamliel in alleyway in Jerusalem, Rabban Gamliel said to his sons: Hurry and take out that you wish to take out, and bring in that you wish to bring in, before that loathsome takes out and prohibits you as he renounced his rights in your favor; the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: And it was taught: One who dwells with a non-Jew, Sadducee, or Boethusian - these prohibit upon him. (Rabban Gamliel says: Sadducee and Boethusian do not prohibit.) And there was an incident with one Sadducee who was dwelling with Rabban Gamliel in a courtyard in Jerusalem, and Rabban Gamliel said to his sons: My sons, hurry and take out what you are taking out and bring in what you are bringing in, until this abomination does not go out and become prohibited upon you, for he has relinquished his rights to you, the words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּלָשׁוֹן אַחֶרֶת — מַהֲרוּ וַעֲשׂוּ צוֹרְכֵיכֶם בַּמָּבוֹי, עַד שֶׁלֹּא תֶּחְשַׁךְ וְיֶאֱסֹר עֲלֵיכֶם.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: with a different formulation, Hurry and do whatever you must do in the alleyway before night falls and he prohibits you
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehudah says: In another language - Hurry and do your needs in the alleyway, before it gets dark and becomes forbidden upon you.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: הוֹצִיאוּ מַה שֶּׁאַתֶּם מוֹצִיאִין, וְהַכְנִיסוּ מַה שֶּׁאַתֶּם מַכְנִיסִין, עַד שֶׁלֹּא יוֹצִיא הַתּוֹעֵב הַזֶּה וְיֶאֱסֹר עֲלֵיכֶם. לְמֵימְרָא דְּכִי מַפְּקִי אִינְהוּ וַהֲדַר מַפֵּיק אִיהוּ לָא אָסַר?!
human_translation: The Master said Take out that you wish to take out, and bring in that you wish to bring in, before that loathsome takes out and prohibits you Is that to say that, if they took out and then took out his he does not render prohibited
llm_translation: Master said: Take out what you take out, and bring in what you bring in, until this abomination does not go out and prohibit you. Is it to say that when they take it out and then bring it back, it does not prohibit?!

hebrew_text: וְהָתְנַן מִי שֶׁנָּתַן רְשׁוּתוֹ וְהוֹצִיא, בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד — אוֹסֵר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: But didn’t we learn one gave his rights he carried out whether unwittingly or intentionally, he renders it prohibited the statement of Rabbi Meir.
llm_translation: And we learned in a Mishnah: One who gave his permission and brought out, whether inadvertently or intentionally - he is liable, the words of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: אֵימָא ״אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר״. אַבָּיֵי אָמַר, לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן — שֶׁהֶחֱזִיקוּ בְּנֵי מָבוֹי בַּמָּבוֹי, כָּאן — שֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיקוּ בְּנֵי מָבוֹי בַּמָּבוֹי.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: Say He does not render it prohibited. Abaye said: not difficult, Here, where the residents of the alleyway had taken possession of the alleyway here, where the residents of the alleyway had not taken possession of the alleyway
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: Why "he does not prohibit"? Abaye said, it is not difficult: here - where the residents of the alleyway have established an ownership in the alleyway, here - where the residents of the alleyway have not established an ownership in the alleyway.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: עַד שֶׁלֹּא נָתַן רְשׁוּתוֹ, הוֹצִיא בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד — יָכוֹל לְבַטֵּל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּשׁוֹגֵג יָכוֹל לְבַטֵּל, בְּמֵזִיד אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְבַטֵּל.
human_translation: And it was taught if he carried before he gave his rights whether unwittingly or intentionally, he can renounce the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: unwittingly he can renounce intentionally, he cannot renounce
llm_translation: And it was taught in a Baraita: Until he has not given his permission, he may remove it, whether it was done inadvertently or intentionally — he can annul, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: If it was done inadvertently, he can annul; if it was done intentionally, he cannot annul.

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁנָּתַן רְשׁוּתוֹ וְהוֹצִיא, בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד — אוֹסֵר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּמֵזִיד אוֹסֵר, בְּשׁוֹגֵג אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר. בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּשֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיקוּ בְּנֵי מָבוֹי בַּמָּבוֹי, אֲבָל הֶחְזִיקוּ בְּנֵי מָבוֹי בַּמָּבוֹי, בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג וּבֵין בְּמֵזִיד — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: one gave his rights he carried whether unwittingly or intentionally, he renders prohibited the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: intentionally, he renders prohibited; inadvertently, he does not render prohibited. In what is this statement said? In where the residents of the alleyway had not taken possession of the alleyway. But if the residents of the alleyway had taken possession of the alleyway whether unwittingly or intentionally, he does not render prohibited
llm_translation: One who gave his permission and brought out, whether unintentionally or intentionally - he prohibits, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: intentionally he prohibits, unintentionally he does not prohibit. In what case are these words said? - When the residents of the alleyway did not establish an eruv for the alleyway, but if the residents of the alleyway established an eruv for the alleyway, whether unintentionally or intentionally - he does not prohibit.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר בְּלָשׁוֹן אַחֶרֶת: מַהֲרוּ וַעֲשׂוּ צוֹרְכֵיכֶם בַּמָּבוֹי עַד שֶׁלֹּא תֶּחְשַׁךְ וְיֶאֱסֹר עֲלֵיכֶם. אַלְמָא גּוֹי הוּא. וְהָא אֲנַן ״עַד שֶׁלֹּא יוֹצִיא״ תְּנַן!
human_translation: The Master said Rabbi Yehuda says: with a different formulation, Hurry, and do whatever you must do in the alleyway before night falls, and he will render prohibited your It is apparent is a gentile, But didn’t we learn before he takes out yotzi
llm_translation: The Master said: Rabbi Yehuda says in another language: Hurry and make your needs in the alleyway before it gets dark and it becomes forbidden for you. This implies that he is a non-Jew. But we learned: "until he takes out"!

hebrew_text: אֵימָא ״עַד שֶׁלֹּא יוֹצִיא הַיּוֹם״. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא, לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן — בְּמוּמָר לְחַלֵּל שַׁבָּתוֹת בְּצִנְעָא, כָּאן — בְּמוּמָר לְחַלֵּל שַׁבָּתוֹת בְּפַרְהֶסְיָא.
human_translation: Say before the day goes out yotzi hayom And if you wish, say: not difficult. Here, to an apostate who desecrates Shabbat in private; here, to an apostate who desecrates Shabbat in public [ befarhesya ].
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima 'ad she'lo yotzi hayom." Ve'ibayit eima, la kashya: kan - b'mumar lechalel shabatot b'tzina'a, kan - b'mumar lechalel shabatot b'farhesya. English translation: "Say, 'until he does not go out today.'" And if you ask, it is not difficult: here - with intent to desecrate the Sabbaths in private, here - with intent to desecrate the Sabbaths in public.

hebrew_text: כְּמַאן אָזְלָא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: מוּמָר וְגִילּוּי פָּנִים הֲרֵי זֶה אֵינוֹ מְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת. גִּילּוּי פָּנִים — מוּמָר הָוֵי?
human_translation: In accordance with which is that was taught An apostate or a brazen-faced may not renounce his rights brazen-faced is an apostate?
llm_translation: As to where did it go, this one that it teaches: a blemish and open declaration of face, behold this one does not annul permission. Open declaration of face - is it considered a blemish?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: מוּמָר בְּגִילּוּי פָּנִים — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת, כְּמַאן כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Rather, A brazen-faced apostate, may not renounce his rights In accordance with whose in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Rather: A blemish in the disclosure of the face — he cannot annul the permission, as according to Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא דִּנְפַק בְּחוּמַרְתָּא דִמְדוּשָׁא. כֵּיוָן דְּחַזְיֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה נְשִׂיאָה, כַּסְּיַיהּ. אָמַר: כְּגוֹן זֶה מְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: a certain went out with a coral ring When he saw Rabbi Yehuda Nesia he covered it. said: such as this, may renounce his rights according to Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: That one who went out with a cloak of Medusha wool. Once Rabbi Yehuda the Prince saw him, he covered himself. He said: "This one is like someone who nullifies the authority of Rabbi Yehuda."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: אֵיזֶהוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל מוּמָר — זֶה הַמְחַלֵּל שַׁבָּתוֹת בְּפַרְהֶסְיָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב נַחְמָן: כְּמַאן? אִי כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר דְּאָמַר: חָשׁוּד לְדָבָר אֶחָד, — חָשׁוּד לְכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ, אֲפִילּוּ בְּאֶחָד מִכׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה נָמֵי.
human_translation: Rav Huna said: Who is an apostate Jew? one who desecrates Shabbat in public. Rav Naḥman said to him: In accordance with If in accordance with Rabbi Meir, said: One who is suspected of one matter, is suspected of the entire Torah, even one of all the prohibitions of the Torah as well,
llm_translation: Rav Huna said: Who is a rebellious Israelite? This is one who desecrates the Sabbaths in public. Rav Nachman said to him: According to whom? If according to Rabbi Meir who said: Suspected in one matter, suspected in the entire Torah, even in one of all the prohibitions in the Torah.

hebrew_text: אִי כְּרַבָּנַן, הָאָמְרִי: חָשׁוּד לְדָבָר אֶחָד לָא הָוֵי חָשׁוּד לְכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ,
human_translation: If in accordance with the Rabbis, Didn’t they say: suspected of one matter is not suspected of the entire Torah,
llm_translation: If like Rabbanan, the saying: suspected for one thing not is suspected for the entire Torah all of it.

hebrew_text: עַד דְּהָוֵי מוּמָר לַעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה.
human_translation: unless he is an apostate with regard to idolatry.
llm_translation: Until he becomes disqualified for foreign service.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: לִיתֵּן רְשׁוּת וּלְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת. וְכִדְתַנְיָא: יִשְׂרָאֵל מוּמָר, מְשַׁמֵּר שַׁבַּתּוֹ בַּשּׁוּק — מְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת, שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְשַׁמֵּר שַׁבַּתּוֹ בַּשּׁוּק — אֵינוֹ מְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: giving rights or renouncing rights And as it was taught An apostate Jew, observes his Shabbat in the marketplace, he may renounce rights does not observe his Shabbat in the marketplace, he may not renounce rights
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: to give permission and to annul permission. And as it was taught: A Jew who is careful to observe his Sabbath in the marketplace — he annuls permission; one who is not careful to observe his Sabbath in the marketplace — he does not annul permission.

hebrew_text: מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאָמְרוּ: יִשְׂרָאֵל נוֹטֵל רְשׁוּת וְנוֹתֵן רְשׁוּת. וּבְגוֹי, עַד שֶׁיַּשְׂכִּיר. כֵּיצַד? אוֹמֵר לוֹ: רְשׁוּתִי קְנוּיָה לָךְ, רְשׁוּתִי מְבוּטֶּלֶת לָךְ — קָנָה, וְאֵין צָרִיךְ לִזְכּוֹת.
human_translation: due to that said: A Jew may receive rights and give rights but with regard to a gentile unless he rents out. How so? may say to May my rights be acquired by you, May my rights be renounced to you, acquires and it is not necessary that he take possession of it
llm_translation: Because they said: Israel takes permission and gives permission. And with a gentile, until he rents. How so? He says to him: "My permission is acquired for you, my permission is annulled for you" - he acquires, and there is no need to validate.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: הַאי תַּנָּא הוּא דַּחֲמִירָא עֲלֵיהּ שַׁבָּת כַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said: It this tanna , for whom Shabbat is as severe as idolatry,
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: This Tanna is stringent regarding Shabbat like Avodah Zarah.

hebrew_text: כִּדְתַנְיָא: ״מִכֶּם״ — וְלֹא כּוּלְּכֶם, פְּרָט לַמּוּמָר. ״מִכֶּם״ — בָּכֶם חִלַּקְתִּי, וְלֹא בָּאוּמּוֹת.
human_translation: As it was taught “Of you,” not all of you to the exclusion of an apostate. “Of you” among you, I distinguish but not among the nations,
llm_translation: As it was taught: "From you" - and not from all of you, excluding the apostate. "From you" - among you I have divided, and not among the nations.

hebrew_text: ״מִן הַבְּהֵמָה״ — לְהָבִיא בְּנֵי אָדָם הַדּוֹמִין לִבְהֵמָה. מִכָּאן אָמְרוּ: מְקַבְּלִין קׇרְבָּנוֹת מִפּוֹשְׁעֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, כְּדֵי שֶׁיַּחְזְרוּ בִּתְשׁוּבָה. חוּץ מִן הַמּוּמָר, וְהַמְנַסֵּךְ יַיִן, וְהַמְחַלֵּל שַׁבָּתוֹת בְּפַרְהֶסְיָא.
human_translation: “Of the cattle” To include people who are similar to animals From here stated: We accept sacrifices from Jewish transgressors, in order to repent, apart from the apostate, one who pours wine libations and one who desecrates Shabbat in public,
llm_translation: "From the animal" — to bring human beings who are similar to animals. From here they said: They accept offerings from the sinners of Israel, so that they may repent. Except for the apostate, the one who pours wine libations, and one who desecrates the Sabbath publicly.

hebrew_text: הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא: אָמְרַתְּ ״מִכֶּם״ וְלֹא כּוּלְּכֶם, לְהוֹצִיא אֶת הַמּוּמָר. וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי: מְקַבְּלִין קׇרְבָּנוֹת מִפּוֹשְׁעֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל! הָא לָא קַשְׁיָא: רֵישָׁא — בְּמוּמָר לְכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ, מְצִיעֲתָא — בְּמוּמָר לְדָבָר אֶחָד.
human_translation: This itself is difficult, You said: “Of you,” but not all of you, to the exclusion of an apostate; and then you taught: We accept sacrifices from Jewish transgressors. This is not difficult, The first clause to an apostate with regard to the entire Torah, the middle clause of an apostate with regard to one matter
llm_translation: The matter is difficult: it says "from among you" and not all of you, to exclude the rebellious one. And then it teaches: they accept sacrifices from the sinners of Israel! This is not difficult: the beginning — with a blemish for the entire Torah, the conclusion — with a blemish for one specific matter.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא סֵיפָא: חוּץ מִן הַמּוּמָר וְהַמְנַסֵּךְ יַיִן. הַאי מוּמָר, הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִי מוּמָר לְכׇל הַתּוֹרָה — הַיְינוּ רֵישָׁא. אִי לְדָבָר אֶחָד, קַשְׁיָא מְצִיעֲתָא.
human_translation: say the last clause Apart from the apostate and one who pours wine libations This apostate, what are the circumstances If an apostate with regard to the entire Torah, this is the first clause. if an apostate with regard to one thing, the middle clause difficult,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Eima seifa: chutz min ha-mumar ve-ha-menassek yayin. Hai mumar, heichi damei? I mumar le'chol ha-Torah — haynu reishah. I le'davar echad, kashya metzi'ata. English translation: The final clause: Except for the apostate and the one who pours wine. What is the case of an apostate? If he is an apostate regarding the entire Torah — that is the beginning. If it is for a specific matter, it is a difficult question.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו הָכִי קָאָמַר: חוּץ מִן הַמּוּמָר לְנַסֵּךְ וּלְחַלֵּל שַׁבָּתוֹת בְּפַרְהֶסְיָא. אַלְמָא עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וְשַׁבָּת כִּי הֲדָדֵי נִינְהוּ. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Rather, is it not that this is it is saying: Apart from the apostate with regard to pouring wine libations and desecrating Shabbat in public? It is apparent idolatry and Shabbat are equivalent, learn from this
llm_translation: Rather, this is what he is saying: Except for the apostate to pour libations and desecrate the Sabbaths in public. It implies that idolatry and Sabbath are equivalent. Learn from this.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אַנְשֵׁי חָצֵר שֶׁשָּׁכַח אֶחָד מֵהֶן וְלֹא עֵירַב — בֵּיתוֹ אָסוּר מִלְּהַכְנִיס וּמִלְּהוֹצִיא לוֹ וְלָהֶם, וְשֶׁלָּהֶם מוּתָּרִין לוֹ וְלָהֶם. נָתְנוּ לוֹ רְשׁוּתָן — הוּא מוּתָּר, וְהֵן אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: If one of the residents of a courtyard forgot and did not participate in an eiruv his house is prohibited to him, and to them, to bring in or to take out But their are permitted to him and to them, If they gave their rights to him, he is permitted but they are prohibited
llm_translation: It was taught in a Mishnah: The residents of a courtyard who forgot one of them and did not join in an Eruv - his house is prohibited from bringing in and taking out for him and for them, but theirs is permitted for him and for them. If they gave him permission - he is permitted, and they are prohibited.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ שְׁנַיִם — אוֹסְרִין זֶה עַל זֶה. שֶׁאֶחָד נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּת וְנוֹטֵל רְשׁוּת, שְׁנַיִם נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּת וְאֵין נוֹטְלִין רְשׁוּת.
human_translation: If two they prohibit one another. For one may give away and receive rights two may give away rights but they may not receive rights
llm_translation: If there are two - they both prohibit each other. If one gives permission and takes permission, two give permission and do not take permission.

hebrew_text: מֵאֵימָתַי נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּת? בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם. בֵּית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: מִשֶּׁחָשֵׁיכָה. מִי שֶׁנָּתַן רְשׁוּתוֹ וְהוֹצִיא, בֵּין בְּשׁוֹגֵג בֵּין בְּמֵזִיד — הֲרֵי זֶה אוֹסֵר, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּמֵזִיד אוֹסֵר, בְּשׁוֹגֵג אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: When may one give rights Beit Shammai say: While it is still day, and Beit Hillel say: Even after nightfall, one gave away his rights and he carried out whether unwittingly, or intentionally, he prohibited the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: intentionally, he prohibited; unwittingly, he does not prohibited.
llm_translation: From when do we establish permission? Beit Shammai says: from before day. Beit Hillel says: from when it becomes dark. One who gives his permission and brings out, whether inadvertently or intentionally — this one prohibits, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: intentionally prohibits, inadvertently does not prohibit.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ בֵּיתוֹ הוּא דְּאָסוּר, הָא חֲצֵירוֹ שַׁרְיָא.
human_translation: it is carrying his house is prohibited, but carrying his courtyard is permitted
llm_translation: "Gema's house is forbidden, but his courtyard is permitted."

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִי דְּבַטֵּיל, בֵּיתוֹ אַמַּאי אָסוּר. אִי דְּלָא בַּטֵּיל, חֲצֵירוֹ אַמַּאי שַׁרְיָא? הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן, כְּגוֹן שֶׁבִּיטֵּל רְשׁוּת חֲצֵירוֹ, וְלֹא בִּיטֵּל רְשׁוּת בֵּיתוֹ. וְקָא סָבְרִי רַבָּנַן: הַמְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת חֲצֵירוֹ — רְשׁוּת בֵּיתוֹ לֹא בִּיטֵּל, דְּדָיַיר אִינִישׁ בְּבַיִת בְּלָא חָצֵר.
human_translation: What are the circumstances If renounced why is his house prohibited? if he did not renounce why is his courtyard permitted? With what are we dealing here? with where he renounced his rights in his courtyard but did not renounce his rights in his house And the Rabbis hold that one who renounces his rights in his courtyard has not renounced his rights in his house, for people to reside in a house without a courtyard.
llm_translation: "How are the laws similar? If he nullifies his ownership, why is his house prohibited? If he does not nullify his ownership, why is his courtyard permitted? What are we dealing with here? For example, when he nullified the ownership of his courtyard but did not nullify the ownership of his house. And the Rabbis hold: one who nullifies the ownership of his courtyard - he did not nullify the ownership of his house, for a person dwells in a house without a courtyard."

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁלָּהֶן מוּתָּר לוֹ וְלָהֶן, מַאי טַעְמָא? דְּהָוֵי אוֹרֵחַ לְגַבַּיְיהוּ.
human_translation: their is permitted for him and for them. What is the reason For he is like a guest of theirs,
llm_translation: And of theirs permitted to him and to them, what is the reason? Because it is considered as his own way.

hebrew_text: נָתְנוּ לוֹ רְשׁוּתָן, הוּא מוּתָּר וְהֵן אֲסוּרִין. וְנֶהֱוֵי אִינְהוּ לְגַבֵּיהּ כִּי אוֹרְחִין! חַד לְגַבֵּי חֲמִשָּׁה — הָוֵי אוֹרֵחַ, חֲמִשָּׁה לְגַבֵּי חַד — לָא הָוֵי אוֹרֵחַ.
human_translation: If gave their rights to him, he is permitted but they are prohibited But let them, be guests of his, One vis-à-vis five is a guest, five vis-à-vis one are not guests.
llm_translation: They gave him their permission, he is permitted and they are forbidden. And they are considered as guests in relation to him! One against five — he is considered a guest, five against one — he is not considered a guest.

hebrew_text: שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ, מְבַטְּלִין וְחוֹזְרִין וּמְבַטְּלִין.
human_translation: learn from this, one may renounce and then may renounce
llm_translation: Listen, infer from it, we nullify and return, and nullify.

hebrew_text: הָכִי קָאָמַר: נָתְנוּ לוֹ רְשׁוּתָן מֵעִיקָּרָא — הוּא מוּתָּר וְהֵן אֲסוּרִין.
human_translation: this is is saying: If they gave away their rights to him at the outset, permitted him and prohibited for them.
llm_translation: So it is stated: If they gave him their permission from the outset - he is permitted, and they are forbidden.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ שְׁנַיִם אוֹסְרִין זֶה עַל זֶה. פְּשִׁיטָא? לָא צְרִיכָא, דַּהֲדַר חַד מִינַּיְיהוּ וּבַטֵּיל לֵיהּ לְחַבְרֵיהּ. מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא לִישְׁתְּרֵי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּכֵיוָן דִּבְעִידָּנָא דְּבַטֵּיל לָא הֲוָה לֵיהּ שַׁרְיוּתָא בְּהַאי חָצֵר.
human_translation: If two they one another prohibited obvious? No, is necessary one of them then renounced in favor of the other. Lest you say let it be permitted teaches us since at the time of his renunciation not permitted in that courtyard,
llm_translation: Two were prohibiting each other. Obvious? Not necessary, as one of them retracts and annuls it to his colleague. What might you say, that they will be permitted? It is evident to us that since he retracts, there was no valid prohibition in this courtyard.

hebrew_text: שֶׁאֶחָד נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּת. הָא תּוּ לְמָה לִי? אִי נוֹתֵן — תְּנֵינָא, אִי נוֹטֵל — תְּנֵינָא?
human_translation: For one may give away rights Why I this further If giving we learned if receiving we learned
llm_translation: One gives permission. The other: Why do I need it? If he gives - we learn; if he takes - we learn?

hebrew_text: סֵיפָא אִיצְטְרִיכָא לֵיהּ: שְׁנַיִם נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּת. הָא נָמֵי פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא
human_translation: He needed the latter clause, two may give away rights this as well, obvious. lest you say:
llm_translation: The latter part requires it: two give permission. This is obvious! What might you think...

hebrew_text: לִיגְזַר דִּילְמָא אָתֵי לְבַטּוֹלֵי לְהוּ. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Let us issue a decree lest come to renounce in favor teaches us
llm_translation: To decree, perhaps he will come to nullify it. This implies to us.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין נוֹטְלִין רְשׁוּת. לְמָה לִי? לָא צְרִיכָא, אַף עַל גַּב דְּאָמְרִי לֵיהּ: קְנִי עַל מְנָת לְהַקְנוֹת.
human_translation: But may not receive rights Why do I No, necessary even if say to Acquire on condition that you transfer
llm_translation: "And we do not take possession. Why do I need it? It is not necessary, even though they say to him: 'Acquire in order to acquire.'"

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ אַבָּיֵי מֵרַבָּה: חֲמִשָּׁה שֶׁשְּׁרוּיִין בְּחָצֵר אַחַת, וְשָׁכַח אֶחָד מֵהֶן וְלֹא עֵירַב, כְּשֶׁהוּא מְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּתוֹ צָרִיךְ לְבַטֵּל לְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד אוֹ לָא? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: צָרִיךְ לְבַטֵּל לְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד.
human_translation: Abaye raised a dilemma before Rabba: five live in the same courtyard, and one of them forgot to join in an eiruv , when he renounces his rights must he renounce in favor of each and every one or not? said to him: He must renounce in favor of each and every one.
llm_translation: Abaye asked Rabba: Five who are dependent in one courtyard, and one of them forgot and did not participate in the Eruv, when he nullifies his domain, does he need to nullify it for each individual or not? He said to him: He needs to nullify it for each individual.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: אֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב, שְׁנַיִם שֶׁעֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב, וּשְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לִשְׁנַיִם שֶׁעֵירְבוּ, אוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב.
human_translation: raised an objection One who did not establish an eiruv may renounce his rights in favor of one who did establish an eiruv . Two who established an eiruv may renounce their rights in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv . And two who did not establish an eiruv may renounce their rights in favor of two who did establish an eiruv or in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv .
llm_translation: He raised an objection to it: One who did not participate in the Eruv may transfer his domain to one who did participate, two who participated may transfer their domains to one who did not participate, and two who did not participate may transfer their domains to two who did participate, or to one who did not participate.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל לֹא אֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב, וְאֵין שְׁנַיִם שֶׁעֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לִשְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ, וְאֵין שְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לִשְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ.
human_translation: But one who did establish an eiruv may not renounce his rights in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv , nor may two who established an eiruv renounce their rights in favor of two who did not establish an eiruv , nor may two who did not establish an eiruv renounce their rights in favor of two who did not establish an eiruv .
llm_translation: But not one who has made an Eruv may give his permission to one who has not made an Eruv, and two who have made an Eruv may not give their permission to two who have not made an Eruv, and two who have not made an Eruv may not give their permission to two who have not made an Eruv.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי מִיהַת רֵישָׁא: אֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב — נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִי דְּלֵיכָּא אַחֲרִינָא בַּהֲדֵיהּ, בַּהֲדֵי מַאן עֵירַב?
human_translation: In any event the first clause is teaching: One who did not establish an eiruv may renounce his rights in favor of one who did establish an eiruv . What are the circumstances If there is no other with him, with whom did he, establish an eiruv ?
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches in the beginning: If one did not participate in the Eruv, he gives his permission to one who did participate. What is the case? If there is no one else with him, who participated in the Eruv?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא — דְּאִיכָּא אַחֲרִינָא בַּהֲדֵיהּ, וְקָתָנֵי: לְאֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב!
human_translation: Rather, obvious that there is another with him, and it states: in favor of one who did establish an eiruv ,
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious - that there is another opinion in agreement with it, and it is taught: "to one who is pleasing!"

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּה: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן, דַּהֲוָה וּמִית.
human_translation: And Rabba With what are we dealing here? where there was but died
llm_translation: Rabba: Here, with what are we dealing, that it was and died.

hebrew_text: אִי דַּהֲוָה וּמִית — אֵימָא סֵיפָא, אֲבָל אֵין אֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב. וְאִי דַּהֲוָה וּמִית, אַמַּאי לָא!
human_translation: If where there was but he died, say the latter clause But one who did establish an eiruv may not renounce his rights in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv . Now if where there was but he died, why not
llm_translation: If he was alive and died - say the latter part, but if one partner gave his consent to another who did not give his consent, and if he was alive and died, why not!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא דְּאִיתֵיהּ. וּמִדְּסֵיפָא אִיתֵיהּ, רֵישָׁא נָמֵי אִיתֵיהּ.
human_translation: Rather, obvious that there is And since the latter clause where there is the first clause where there is
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious that he has it. And from the continuation, he has it; at the beginning, he also has it.

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי אִירְיָא? הָא כִּדְאִיתָא, וְהָא כִּדְאִיתָא.
human_translation: Is this the designation in both This as it is, and this as it is,
llm_translation: From the city of Irya? This one as it was stated, and this one as it was stated.

hebrew_text: תֵּדַע, דְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא דְּרֵישָׁא: וּשְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ, נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לִשְׁנַיִם שֶׁעֵירְבוּ. לִשְׁנַיִם אִין! לְאֶחָד לָא.
human_translation: Know for the last of the first clause teaches: And two who did not establish an eiruv may renounce their rights in favor of two who did establish an eiruv . in favor of two yes, in favor of one, no,
llm_translation: You should know, as it is taught in the latter part of the beginning: "And two who did not combine, they give their permission to two who did combine. To two? No! To one, yes."

hebrew_text: וְאַבָּיֵי אָמַר: מַאי ״לִשְׁנַיִם״ — לְאֶחָד מִשְּׁנַיִם. אִי הָכִי לִיתְנֵי: לְאֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב אוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב. קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: And Abaye say: What in favor of two? In favor of one of the two, If so, let it teach in favor of one who established an eiruv or in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv , difficult
llm_translation: And Abbaye said: What is "for two" - for one of two. If so, let it teach: for one who mixed or for one who did not mix. This is difficult.

hebrew_text: אֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב. לְאַבָּיֵי דְּאִיתֵיהּ, וְקָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: דְּאֵין צָרִיךְ לְבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת לְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד. לְרַבָּה דַּהֲוָה וּמִית, וְלָא גְּזוּר זִימְנִין דְּאִיתֵיהּ.
human_translation: One who did not establish an eiruv may renounce his rights in favor of one who did establish an eiruv . According to Abaye, to where there is and it teaches us he need not renounce his rights in favor of each and every one According to Rabba, where there was but died and did not issue a decree sometimes is present.
llm_translation: One who did not participate gives his permission to one who did participate. According to Abbaye who is present, and he is indicating to us: that it is not necessary to annul permission for each and every individual. According to Rava who was and is no longer, and it is not decreed that he is present.

hebrew_text: וּשְׁנַיִם שֶׁעֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב. פְּשִׁיטָא? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא כֵּיוָן דְּלָא עֵירַב — לִיקְנְסֵיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Two who established an eiruv may renounce their rights in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv . obvious? Lest you say since he did not establish an eiruv , we should penalize him teaches us
llm_translation: Two who have jointly eruv, they give their permission to one who did not participate in the eruv. Is it not obvious? Lest you say, since he did not participate — let him enter, it is taught to us.

hebrew_text: וּשְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לִשְׁנַיִם שֶׁעֵירְבוּ. לְרַבָּה — תְּנָא סֵיפָא לְגַלּוֹיֵי רֵישָׁא, לְאַבָּיֵי — שְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ אִיצְטְרִיכָא לֵיהּ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: לִגְזַר דִּלְמָא אָתֵי לְבַטּוֹלֵי לְהוּ. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: And two who did not establish an eiruv may renounce their rights in favor of two who established an eiruv . According to Rabba, taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause. According to Abaye, necessary two who did not establish an eiruv . it could enter your mind to say we should issue a decree lest come to renounce in favor of teaches us
llm_translation: Two that did not combine, give their domain to two that did combine. According to Rabbah - the latter clause is to clarify the former; according to Abbaye - two that did not combine is necessary for him. It is reasonable to say: to decree lest one come to annul them. This is what we hear.

hebrew_text: אוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב. לְמָה לִי? מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: הָנֵי מִילֵּי — הֵיכָא דְּמִקְצָתָן עֵירְבוּ וּמִקְצָתָן לֹא עֵירְבוּ. אֲבָל הֵיכָא דְּכוּלָּן לֹא עֵירְבוּ — לִיקְנְסִינְהוּ, כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא תִּשְׁתַּכַּח תּוֹרַת עֵירוּב, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Or in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv . Why do I Lest you say these rulings apply only where some of established an eiruv and some of them did not establish an eiruv . But where none of established an eiruv , we should penalize them so that the category of eiruv should not be forgotten teaches us
llm_translation: Or to one who did not participate. Why do I need it? What might you say: These words - where some of them participated and some did not participate. But where none of them participated - we penalize them, so that the law of eruv will not be forgotten, it is heard for us.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל אֵין אֶחָד שֶׁעֵירַב נוֹתֵן רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד שֶׁלֹּא עֵירַב. לְאַבָּיֵי — תְּנָא סֵיפָא לְגַלּוֹיֵי רֵישָׁא, לְרַבָּה — אַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא רֵישָׁא תְּנָא נָמֵי סֵיפָא.
human_translation: But one who did establish an eiruv may not renounce his rights in favor of one who did not establish an eiruv . According to Abaye, taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause, According to Rabba, since taught the first clause it also taught the latter clause
llm_translation: But one who mixed does not give his permission to one who did not mix. According to Abbaye - the latter clause is taught to clarify the former clause, according to Rava - since the one who taught the former clause also taught the latter clause.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין שְׁנַיִם שֶׁעֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לִשְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ. הָא תּוּ לְמָה לִי? לָא צְרִיכָא, דְּבַטֵּיל לֵיהּ חַד מִינַּיְיהוּ לְחַבְרֵיהּ. מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: לִשְׁתְּרֵי לֵיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: כֵּיוָן דִּבְעִידָּנָא דְּבַטֵּיל לָא הֲווֹ לֵיהּ שַׁרְיוּתָא בְּהָא חָצֵר — לָא.
human_translation: Nor may two who established an eiruv renounce their rights in favor of two who did not establish an eiruv . Why do I this further No, necessary where one of renounced in favor of his fellow Lest you say it should be permitted teaches us since at the time of his renunciation he was not permitted in that courtyard, not
llm_translation: And two that have not combined, they do not give their permission to two that have not combined. This, what do I need it for? It is not necessary, for he nullifies one of them to his companions. What if you would say: Let him nullify it for him, we learn: since in a case where he nullified, there is no permission for him in this courtyard — no.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין שְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּתָן לִשְׁנַיִם שֶׁלֹּא עֵירְבוּ. הָא תּוּ לְמָה לִי? לָא צְרִיכָא, דְּאָמְרִי: קְנִי עַל מְנָת לְהִקָּנוֹת.
human_translation: Nor may two who did not establish an eiruv renounce their rights in favor of two who did not establish an eiruv . Why do I this additional No, necessary where said Acquire on condition that you transfer
llm_translation: And two that did not combine, they give their permission to two that did not combine. This, what for me? Not necessary, as they say: Acquire in order to acquire.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רָבָא מֵרַב נַחְמָן: יוֹרֵשׁ מַהוּ שֶׁיְּבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת.
human_translation: Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman: an heir, what is he renounce rights
llm_translation: Requested by Rava from Rav Nachman: An inheritor, what is the law if he should renounce ownership.

hebrew_text: הֵיכָא דְּאִי בָּעֵי לְעָרוֹבֵי מֵאֶתְמוֹל מָצֵי מְעָרֵב — בַּטּוֹלֵי נָמֵי מָצֵי מְבַטֵּל, אֲבָל הַאי כֵּיוָן דְּאִי בָּעֵי לְעָרוֹבֵי מֵאֶתְמוֹל — לָא מָצֵי מְעָרֵב, לָא מָצֵי מְבַטֵּל.
human_translation: where, if wanted to establish an eiruv on the previous day he could have established an eiruv , he can also But this since, if he wanted to establish an eiruv the previous day he could not have established an eiruv , he cannot renounce
llm_translation: Here where if one wants to make an Eruv from yesterday, he finds a loaf, he can make the Eruv - if he finds a loaf of bread, he can nullify it, but in this case, where if one wants to make an Eruv from yesterday, he does not find a loaf, he cannot make the Eruv, he cannot nullify it.

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִּלְמָא: יוֹרֵשׁ כַּרְעֵיהּ דַּאֲבוּהּ הוּא?
human_translation: Or perhaps an heir is his father’s foot,
llm_translation: Or perhaps: does he inherit the legs of his father?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֲנִי אוֹמֵר מְבַטֵּל, וְהָנֵי דְּבֵי שְׁמוּאֵל תָּנוּ אֵין מְבַטֵּל. אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: זֶה הַכְּלָל, כׇּל שֶׁמּוּתָּר לְמִקְצָת שַׁבָּת — הוּתַּר לְכׇל הַשַּׁבָּת, וְכׇל שֶׁנֶּאְסַר לְמִקְצָת שַׁבָּת — נֶאְסַר לְכׇל הַשַּׁבָּת חוּץ מִמְּבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת.
human_translation: said to him: I say can renounce while those the school of Shmuel taught: He cannot renounce raised an objection to This is the principle: Anything that is permitted for part of Shabbat is permitted for all of Shabbat, and anything that is prohibited for part of Shabbat is prohibited for all of Shabbat, apart from one who renounces his rights
llm_translation: He said to him: I say it is nullified, and the House of Shmuel taught: it is not nullified. They raised an objection against him: This is the principle: anything that is permitted for part of Shabbat - is permitted for the entire Shabbat, and anything that is forbidden for part of Shabbat - is forbidden for the entire Shabbat except for nullifying a domain.

hebrew_text: כׇּל שֶׁהוּתַּר לְמִקְּצָת שַׁבָּת, מוּתָּר לְכׇל הַשַּׁבָּת — כְּגוֹן עֵירַב דֶּרֶךְ הַפֶּתַח, וְנִסְתַּם הַפֶּתַח. עֵירַב דֶּרֶךְ חַלּוֹן, וְנִסְתַּם חַלּוֹן.
human_translation: Anything that is permitted for part of Shabbat is permitted for all of Shabbat. For example, an eiruv was established via an opening and opening was closed up an eiruv was established via a window and window was closed up
llm_translation: All that was permitted for part of Shabbat, is permitted for the entire Shabbat — for example, an eruv by way of the doorway, and the doorway became sealed. An eruv by way of the window, and the window became sealed.

hebrew_text: זֶה הַכְּלָל — לְאֵתוֹיֵי מָבוֹי שֶׁנִּיטְּלוּ קוֹרוֹתָיו אוֹ לְחָיָיו.
human_translation: this is the principle to include an alleyway whose beams or side posts were removed
llm_translation: This is the principle - to include a passageway whose beams or walls were removed.

hebrew_text: כׇּל שֶׁנֶּאְסַר לְמִקְצָת שַׁבָּת, נֶאְסַר לְכׇל הַשַּׁבָּת כּוּלָּהּ — כְּגוֹן שְׁנֵי בָתִּים בִּשְׁנֵי צִידֵּי רְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים, וְהִקִּיפוּם גּוֹיִם מְחִיצָה בְּשַׁבָּת.
human_translation: Anything that is prohibited for part of Shabbat is prohibited for all of Shabbat. For example, two houses on two sides of a public domain, which gentiles enclosed with a wall on Shabbat,
llm_translation: All that was prohibited for part of Shabbat, is prohibited for the entire Shabbat - for example, two houses on two sides of a public domain, and non-Jews surrounded them with a partition on Shabbat.

hebrew_text: זֶה הַכְּלָל לְאֵתוֹיֵי מַאי? לְאֵתוֹיֵי מֵת גּוֹי בְּשַׁבָּת.
human_translation: What this is the principle to include to include a gentile died on Shabbat
llm_translation: This is the principle: What does it come to include? It comes to include a non-Jew who dies on Shabbat.

hebrew_text: וְקָתָנֵי: חוּץ מִמְּבַטֵּל רְשׁוּת. אִיהוּ — אִין, יוֹרֵשׁ — לָא.
human_translation: And teaches: Apart from one who renounces his rights He yes, heir, no,
llm_translation: And it is taught: "Outside of the view is nullifying the domain." He - no, inheritor - yes.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא: חוּץ מִתּוֹרַת בִּיטּוּל רְשׁוּת.
human_translation: Say Apart from into the category of one who renounces his rights
llm_translation: Concerning what? Excluding the law of nullification of ownership.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: אֶחָד מִבְּנֵי חָצֵר שֶׁמֵּת, וְהִנִּיחַ רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד מִן הַשּׁוּק, מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם — אוֹסֵר, מִשֶּׁחָשֵׁיכָה — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: raised a objection to a resident of a courtyard died and left his domain, to one from the marketplace, while it was still day, prohibited, after nightfall, he does not prohibited,
llm_translation: He raised an objection: If one of the residents of a courtyard dies and leaves his domain to one of the marketplaces, from the moment he left it - he prohibits carrying in the courtyard, from when it gets dark - he does not prohibit carrying.

hebrew_text: וְאֶחָד מִן הַשּׁוּק שֶׁמֵּת וְהִנִּיחַ רְשׁוּתוֹ לְאֶחָד מִבְּנֵי חָצֵר, מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר, מִשֶּׁחָשֵׁיכָה — אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: And one from the marketplace died and left his domain to a resident of the courtyard while it was still day, does not prohibited, after nightfall prohibited.
llm_translation: "And one from the market who died and left his property to one of the members of the courtyard, during the day - he does not prohibit, once it becomes dark - he prohibits."

hebrew_text: אַמַּאי אוֹסֵר? נִיבַטֵּיל! מַאי ״אוֹסֵר״ נָמֵי דְּקָתָנֵי — עַד שֶׁיְּבַטֵּל.
human_translation: why does prohibited Let him renounce What is prohibits that teaches until he renounces
llm_translation: What does he prohibit? He nullifies! What is "prohibit"? Indeed, as it is taught - until he nullifies.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: יִשְׂרָאֵל וְגֵר שְׁרוּיִין בִּמְגוּרָה אַחַת, וּמֵת גֵּר מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם,
human_translation: Come hear a Jew and a convert were living in a single residency and the convert died while it was still day,
llm_translation: Come and hear: Israelite and convert are equal in one dwelling, and if a convert dies during the day,

hebrew_text: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהֶחֱזִיק יִשְׂרָאֵל אַחֵר בִּנְכָסָיו — אוֹסֵר. מִשֶּׁחָשֵׁיכָה, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיק יִשְׂרָאֵל אַחֵר — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: even though a different Jew took possession of property, prohibited. after nightfall, even though a different Jew did not take possession of it, is not prohibited,
llm_translation: Even though Israel held onto his property - he forbids. From when it gets dark, even though Israel did not hold onto it - he does not forbid.

hebrew_text: הָא גוּפָא קַשְׁיָא, אָמְרַתְּ: מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם — אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהֶחְזִיק, וְלָא מִיבַּעְיָא כִּי לֹא הֶחְזִיק. אַדְּרַבָּה, כִּי לֹא הֶחְזִיק לָא אָסַר!
human_translation: itself is difficult. You said: while it was still day, even though a different Jew took possession of it is not necessary where did not take possession of On the contrary, where did not take possession of it is not prohibited,
llm_translation: This is a difficult case, as she said: "From before day" - even though he held, and it is not necessary, for he did not hold. On the contrary, because he did not hold, he did not prohibit!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: אֵימָא: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיק. וְהָא ״אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהֶחְזִיק״ קָתָנֵי?
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: Say Even though did not take possession of But doesn’t it teach: Even though he took possession of
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Say: Even though he did not establish. But isn't it taught "even though he did establish"?

hebrew_text: הָכִי קָאָמַר: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיק מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם אֶלָּא מִשֶּׁחָשֵׁיכָה, כֵּיוָן דַּהֲוָה לֵיהּ לְהַחְזִיק מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם — אוֹסֵר. מִשֶּׁחָשֵׁיכָה, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיק יִשְׂרָאֵל אַחֵר — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: This is is saying: even though did not take possession of while it was still day but after nightfall, since he had of taking possession while it was still day, prohibited. after nightfall, even though a different Jew did not take possession of it does not render prohibited
llm_translation: So it is stated: Even though it did not take hold from before daybreak, but only from nightfall, once it became capable of taking hold from before daybreak - it prohibits. From nightfall, even though another Israel did not take hold - it does not prohibit.

hebrew_text: ״אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיק יִשְׂרָאֵל אַחֵר״, וְלָא מִיבַּעְיָא כִּי הֶחְזִיק?! אַדְּרַבָּה, כִּי הֶחְזִיק אָסַר!
human_translation: even though a different Jew did not take possession of it is not necessary where did take possession of on the contrary, where takes possession of he prohibited.
llm_translation: "Even though Israel did not hold on," and it is not necessary that he held on?! On the contrary, because he held on, he prohibited!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא, אֵימָא: ״אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהֶחְזִיק״. וְהָא ״אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֶחְזִיק״ קָתָנֵי! הָכִי קָאָמַר: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהֶחְזִיק מִשֶּׁחָשֵׁיכָה, כֵּיוָן דְּלָא הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְהַחְזִיק מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם — אֵינוֹ אוֹסֵר.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: Say Even though took possession of But didn’t teach: Even though he did not take possession of This is is saying: even though took possession of after nightfall, since he did not have of taking possession while it was still day, he does not prohibited.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Say, "Even though he held." But isn't it taught, "Even though he did not hold"? This is what it means to say: Even though he held from when it became dark, since he did not have the ability to hold from earlier in the day - it does not prohibit.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי מִיהַת רֵישָׁא אוֹסֵר, אַמַּאי אוֹסֵר? נִיבַטֵּל!
human_translation: In any event, the first clause is teaching renders prohibited; why does he render prohibited? Let him renounce
llm_translation: The text states: "It was taught in one place: he forbids. Why does he forbid? It is nullified!"

hebrew_text: מַאי ״אוֹסֵר״ דְּקָתָנֵי — עַד שֶׁיְּבַטֵּל.
human_translation: What is prohibits that it teaches until he renounces
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "osair" that is taught? - Until it is nullified.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: מַתְנִיתִין, מַנִּי? — בֵּית שַׁמַּאי הִיא, דְּאָמְרִי: אֵין בִּיטּוּל רְשׁוּת בְּשַׁבָּת. דִּתְנַן: מֵאֵימָתַי נוֹתְנִין רְשׁוּת? בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: מִבְּעוֹד יוֹם, וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: מִשֶּׁתֶּחְשַׁךְ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who is the tanna of the baraitot It is Beit Shammai, who say there is no renunciation of rights on Shabbat As we learned When may one give away rights Beit Shammai say: While it is still day. And Beit Hillel say: after nightfall.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: "Matnitin, mani?" - It is Beit Shammai, as they say: There is no nullification of a domain on Shabbat. As we learned: From when do we grant permission? Beit Shammai says: From while it is still day, and Beit Hillel says: From when it becomes dark.

hebrew_text: אָמַר עוּלָּא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּבֵית הִלֵּל, נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר ״כְּלָךְ אֵצֶל יָפוֹת״.
human_translation: Ulla said: What is the reason of Beit Hillel It is comparable to one who says: Turn toward the high-quality ones.
llm_translation: Ulla said: What is the reason for the opinion of Beit Hillel, that it is done as it says, "like a bride by beautiful"?

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מֵת גּוֹי בְּשַׁבָּת מַאי ״כְּלָךְ אֵצֶל יָפוֹת״ אִיכָּא?
human_translation: Abaye said: a gentile dies on Shabbat, what is there to Turn toward the high-quality ones?
llm_translation: Abbaye said: If a gentile dies on Shabbat, what is the law regarding "Kilach Etzel Yafot"?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָכָא בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי: בֵּית שַׁמַּאי סָבְרִי בִּיטּוּל רְשׁוּת מִיקְנֵא רְשׁוּתָא הוּא, וּמִיקְנֵא רְשׁוּתָא בְּשַׁבָּת — אָסוּר. וּבֵית הִלֵּל סָבְרִי אִסְתַּלּוֹקֵי רְשׁוּתָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא, וְאִסְתַּלּוֹקֵי רְשׁוּתָא בְּשַׁבָּת — שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Rather, here they disagree over the following: Beit Shammai hold renunciation of a domain is acquisition of a domain, and acquisition of a domain is prohibited on Shabbat. And Beit Hillel hold it is merely withdrawal from a domain, and withdrawal from a domain seems well on Shabbat,
llm_translation: Rather, here in this case they disagree: Beit Shammai hold that acquiring a domain is considered a valid acquisition, and if one acquires a domain on Shabbat - it is prohibited. But Beit Hillel hold that merely relinquishing ownership is considered a valid relinquishment, and if one relinquishes ownership on Shabbat - it is praiseworthy.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ בַּעַל הַבַּיִת שֶׁהָיָה שׁוּתָּף לִשְׁכֵנָיו, לָזֶה בְּיַיִן וְלָזֶה בְּיַיִן — אֵינָן צְרִיכִין לְעָרֵב.
human_translation: a homeowner was in partnership with his neighbors, with this in wine and with that in wine, they need not establish an eiruv ,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If the homeowner was a partner with his neighbors, one with this wine and one with this wine - they do not need to make an Eruv.

hebrew_text: לָזֶה בְּיַיִן וְלָזֶה בְּשֶׁמֶן — צְרִיכִין לְעָרֵב. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה, אֵינָן צְרִיכִין לְעָרֵב.
human_translation: with this in wine and with that in oil, they must establish an eiruv . Rabbi Shimon says: both this and that they need not establish an eiruv .
llm_translation: For this with wine and for this with oil - need to mix. Rabbi Shimon says: One this and one this, do not need to mix.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב: וּבִכְלִי אֶחָד. אָמַר רָבָא, דַּיְקָא נָמֵי דְּקָתָנֵי: לָזֶה בְּיַיִן וְלָזֶה בְּשֶׁמֶן — צְרִיכִין לְעָרֵב. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא: רֵישָׁא בִּכְלִי אֶחָד, וְסֵיפָא בִּשְׁנֵי כֵלִים — שַׁפִּיר. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ: רֵישָׁא בִּשְׁנֵי כֵלִים, וְסֵיפָא בִּשְׁנֵי כֵלִים — מָה לִי יַיִן וָיַיִן, מָה לִי יַיִן וָשֶׁמֶן?!
human_translation: Rav said: in one vessel. Rava said: is also precise, as it teaches: with this one in wine and with the one in oil, they must establish an eiruv . Granted, if you say the first clause with one vessel, and the latter clause with two vessels, it is well. But, if you say the first clause of two vessels, and the latter clause of two vessels, what to me wine and wine or wine and oil?
llm_translation: Gemara said Rav: And in one vessel. Rava said, it is precisely as it is taught: for this one with wine and for this one with oil - they need to be mixed. If you say, the first part in one vessel, and the latter part in two vessels - it is fine. But if you say: the first part in two vessels, and the latter part in two vessels - what do I need wine and wine for, what do I need wine and oil for?!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: יַיִן וָיַיִן רָאוּי לְעָרֵב. יַיִן וְשֶׁמֶן אֵין רָאוּי לְעָרֵב.
human_translation: Abaye said to him: wine and wine is suitable for mixing Wine and oil, are not suitable for mixing.
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: wine and wine are suitable for mixing. Wine and oil are not suitable for mixing.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר, אֶחָד זֶה וְאֶחָד זֶה — אֵין צְרִיכִין לְעָרֵב. וַאֲפִילּוּ לָזֶה בְּיַיִן וְלָזֶה בְּשֶׁמֶן! אָמַר רַבָּה: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן בְּחָצֵר שֶׁבֵּין שְׁנֵי מְבוֹאוֹת, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן לְטַעְמֵיהּ —
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: both this and that they need not establish an eiruv . even if with this one in wine and with the other one in oil? Rabba said: With what are we dealing here? with a courtyard between two alleyways, and Rabbi Shimon his reasoning.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says, one this and one this - not need to combine. And even this with wine and this with oil! Raba said: Here what we are dealing with? In a courtyard between two entrances, and Rabbi Shimon according to his reasoning -

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: לְמָה הַדָּבָר דּוֹמֶה, לְשָׁלֹשׁ חֲצֵירוֹת הַפְּתוּחוֹת זוֹ לָזוֹ וּפְתוּחוֹת לִרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים. עֵירְבוּ שְׁתַּיִם הַחִיצוֹנוֹת עִם הָאֶמְצָעִית — הִיא מוּתֶּרֶת עִמָּהֶן, וְהֵן מוּתָּרוֹת עִמָּהּ, וּשְׁתַּיִם הַחִיצוֹנוֹת אֲסוּרוֹת זוֹ עִם זוֹ.
human_translation: As we learned Rabbi Shimon said: To what is this matter comparable? to three courtyards that open into one another and open into a public domain.
